PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1.Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2.We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3.This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Ferguson (from 1,924 citizens) and Senator Ian Macdonald (from 16 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the constitutional monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Exports to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
There is general dissatisfaction with the effectiveness of the legislation and industrial award provisions for occupational superannuation, and

We the undersigned therefore respectfully request the Parliament of Australia to amend the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Legislation so as to place the responsibility for providing superannuated retirement benefits onto the person who will eventually receive the retirement benefit.

PETITION.PARA: and further

PARA.TAB: We call upon the Parliament to convene as a matter of urgency a National Summit involving representatives from Trade Unions, Employer Organisations and State and Federal Parliament to develop a national strategy for an equitable mechanism to provide retirees with an adequate retirement income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Homeless Rate Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.TITLE: Leaded Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the Government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
1. Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
2. Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

3. Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
4. Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), reference number CCA/4B/93/2, made under subsection 4C(1) of the Child Care Act 1972, with respect to the Minister's powers under subsection 4B(2) of that Act, be disallowed; and
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 1 February 1994:
An examination of the cost of implementing the guidelines for the accreditation of child care centres.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision by the coalition to move to disallow these accreditation guidelines is not one that has been taken lightly. But the flaws in these guidelines, in particular the decision to link accreditation to eligibility for child-care assistance, have moved the coalition to take the stand reflected in the motion before us today. The other motion before us today is for the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs to be given a reference to examine the costs of implementing the guidelines for the accreditation of child-care centres. This relates closely to the disallowance motion and, hence, my motion to have a cognate debate on these notices of motion.

PARA.TAB: The only certainty about the cost impact of accreditation is that it will be significantly greater than the figure being suggested by the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. I will return to that point later in my speech. In taking the stand to disallow the accreditation guidelines, no-one should lose sight of the fact that the coalition is strongly committed to quality child care. The opening sentence in the introduction to our 1993 child-care policy statement, released during the last election, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Affordable quality child care is a basic right of all parents.
Later in our policy, we state that we will:

. . . encourage parents and the staff of centres to work together to ensure that the available services are of high quality and reflect a continuing commitment to the needs and aspirations of both parents and children.

So there can be no doubting the commitment of the coalition to quality child care. The coalition is also committed to a voluntary system of accreditation, but not to this version of compulsory accreditation put forward by the government. Let there be no misunderstanding. Despite what Senator Crowley claims, the government's version of accreditation is completely compulsory. It is compulsory because the guidelines say that the fee relief will be payable only to parents whose children attend an accredited centre. What message does that send? Obviously, the government is effectively holding a gun to the heads of child-care centres and, indeed, a gun to the heads of parents relying on that relief. If the guidelines are not followed then, as a consequence, no fee relief is obtained.

PARA.TAB: However, the most outrageous aspect of the guidelines before us today is that they do not reflect what the majority of child-care centres want and nor do they reflect what the parents want. The guidelines before us today are not the product of a ground swell of parental concern about the quality of child care provided to their children; rather, the guidelines are the product of a deal which occurred at the time of the 1990 election campaign. I invite anybody to take the trouble to read the guidelines because only then will that person understand the parental concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially the minister.

—Yes, especially the minister. Mr Hawke, in his 1990 election speech, announced that fee relief would be extended to the private sector. However, this extension was bitterly opposed by the ACTU and many child-care activists. It is clear that the price for allowing this to go ahead was a commitment from the government to establish a national accreditation system for all long day child-care centres. In June 1990, the relevant minister, Mr Staples, established a national advisory committee of child-care industry representatives. As is typical of all the subsequent committees established to develop accreditation, this committee was heavily biased against the private sector. It was chaired by Mary Crawford, the honourable member for Forde. The committee reported to Mr Staples in August 1990 and—surprise, surprise—included a recommendation advocating the attachment of quality assurance conditions to receipt of child-care fee relief.

PARA.TAB: In December 1991 the government established the Interim National Accreditation Council, headed by Ms Jane Singleton. Again, the composition of the committee was totally unbalanced. The 16-member committee included just two representatives from the private sector and two parent representatives. The Interim National Accreditation Council presented an interim report to Mr Staples in June 1992 and a final report in November 1992. Just before the interim report of the council, the caucus subcommittee on child care reported to the government on its 1992 child-care consultations. The findings are very illuminating and are absolutely relevant to today's debate.

The committee states in its May 1992 report that the sole purpose of its consultations was to listen to the views of parents, child-care workers and the community and to report those views back to the government. What views did the committee find? Did it find a ground swell of parent concern at the quality of child care being provided to their children? Did it find a ground swell of parents demanding that the government implement a national system of accreditation linked to fee relief?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—I tell Senator Zakharov that it found nothing like that at all. Let me quote some of the important views canvassed by the committee. Under a section headed `Key themes', the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a widespread feeling that the child-care system Australia has now is worth protecting, that we got it about right.
It goes on to state:

Speaker after speaker at public meetings pointed to the fact that Australia currently has one of the best child-care systems in the world. Australia's provision of quality child care is well in advance of many European countries and well in front of both the United States and Britain. In fact, Australia's approach is held up by child-care advocates in those countries as a model.

These were the views that were coming back to the government through its caucus subcommittee on child care. There was no widespread call for a system of compulsory accreditation, but the government ploughed on regardless. At the last election the government confirmed that, if re-elected, it would pursue a national system of accreditation. But what about the link to fee relief? There is no mention of it by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his Investing in the Nation statement. He simply states, `We have decided to introduce a system of national accreditation of child-care centres'. There is not a word about it being compulsory.

PARA.TAB: What does the ALP child-care policy statement say about it? It talks about establishment and operation of the National Child Care Accreditation Council, assessment of centres, development of the handbook and so on. The description of the accreditation system goes on for six paragraphs, but not once is it explicitly stated that accreditation will be linked to fee relief.

Given that this link was so clearly on the agenda coming up to the election, it is worth asking why it was not mentioned in the policy statement. The reason is that cabinet rejected it. There was no cabinet authority for including such a commitment in the policy statement. In fact, according to former Senator Peter Walsh, the attempt to link accreditation to eligibility for fee relief was rejected by cabinet on at least two occasions. We now know that it was not until April of this year, according to the minister, that the cabinet approved making this link. It took three attempts from the bureaucracy, which refused to take no for an answer, before the link actually got up through cabinet. I know that there are a great many people on the other side who are as disappointed with this decision as we are.

Since the election we have seen yet another committee established to oversee accreditation, and this is the National Child Care Accreditation Council. Once again, we find that that council is not truly representative of the child-care sector. There are presently no parent representatives on the council. The final version of the accreditation guidelines which we are debating today has passed through the council without a single representative parent being able to express a view other than those who happen to be parents who are on the council.

Since the council was appointed in July of this year, the two representatives of the private child-care sector have resigned. They resigned because they could no longer tolerate their membership of the council being used by the Minister for Family Services as evidence that the private sector was consulted and supported accreditation.

The private sector, almost without exception, is opposed to the government's accreditation system and, in particular, the link between accreditation and fee relief. The importance of this resistance cannot be overstated because the private sector has the majority of long day child-care places in this country. According to figures based on preliminary 1992 child-care census data, supplied to Senator Newman by the department, around 104,000 long day care places are available in Australia. Of these, 53,920 are provided by private operators. Around 7,450 are provided by employer and non-profit centres. Community based centres provide around 42,800 places. This means that the private sector provides about 52,000 of all child-care places.

When one notes that a significant portion of the non-profit sector is also opposed to the compulsory system being put forward by the government, it becomes clear that the majority of the child-care sector industry opposes these guidelines. That is not the only reason for opposition. I have before me a letter from the Creche and Kindergarten Association of Queensland that has another concern. It is concerned about the possible massive expansion of private commercial child-care centres in Queensland and has expressed concern to the minister about the lack of planning and control exercised by the government and the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services. I know that the minister will get up again and mislead the Senate by suggesting that the private sector is not unified in its approach on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I object to that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Herron, would you like to—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he say?
—He accused the minister of misleading the parliament.

—I withdraw. I will refer to that matter later. The minister has claimed that the private sector in Canberra and Queensland supported these guidelines, including the link to fee relief. This is absolutely wrong. I understand that the minister has received a letter from the President of the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations on behalf of, amongst others, the Queensland and ACT associations refuting the minister's claim. But as the minister finds herself in increasing trouble on these guidelines, as she buckles under the pressure from within her own party, the pressure from parents and child-care centre owners and the pressure from the media, we find that she is having less and less regard for the truth.

PARA.TAB: The minister, in question time on 24 November and again during question time yesterday, in a very disingenuous way, tried to suggest that Senator Newman supported the government's accreditation guidelines. That is an outrageous and totally false claim. On both occasions, I am delighted to say, Senator Newman was constrained to come to the telephone and contact us immediately to refute those claims. On 24 November, she put out a press release refuting those claims. Yet the minister had the absolute gall to repeat those statements subsequently. To my way of thinking, that supports the previous statement that I made and the import of it should be apparent to all. She accused Senator McGauran of using the privileges of parliament and yet did the same herself on two subsequent occasions knowing full well that Senator Newman had refuted the claim that she put forward. It is outrageous and totally false.

There is widespread community concern from parents, from child-care centre operators and, as I saw on television last night, from the Catholic church. There is widespread concern, no matter what the minister says. Only a few weeks ago bus loads of parents came to Parliament House to protest about the linkage. Senator Crowley and her arguments on accreditation were utterly demolished on Sydney radio by John Laws. I would recommend to anybody who wants a bit of light entertainment to read the transcript of that radio interview. I understand now why Mr Laws has a reputation for demolition because, if ever anybody got demolished, it was Senator Crowley. It took her virtually the length of the interview to even concede that, if a satisfactory standard is not achieved on all 52 principles, a centre will not be accredited and parents sending their children to the centre will not be eligible for fee relief.

More importantly, she showed that she has no faith in the ability of parents to determine whether their children are receiving adequate care. I notice that that was mentioned again today. Incredibly, the government seems to hold the belief that it knows better than parents. Under the present system, a parent can take a child out of a child-care centre—

TALK.START.PARA: —We listen to parents.
—Senator Zakharov says that she knows better than parents. It is obvious that she is in collusion and in agreement with what is occurring.

—There is no point of order.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley has taken no notice. She has been positively patronising towards parents. TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong, Senator. State licensing is a requirement, not voluntary.
