—As I said previously, we support a scheme of voluntary accreditation in order to establish a benchmark against which to measure quality. But we will not support a scheme which is made compulsory by linking accreditation to fee relief. As we point out in our policy, parents are entitled to assume that all formal child-care services will meet certain specified standards which will guarantee adequate health and safety provisions, child/staff and space ratios, and staff qualifications. However, there can be no doubt that parents are the best judges of the quality of available services. Parents are the best judges of whether services are appropriate and adequate for their children. It should be parents who choose the quality of care suitable for their children—not some government-appointed agency which seeks to usurp the role of the parent through the state.

PARA.TAB: The argument is sometimes put that the lack of available child-care places means that parents have very little choice in where they send their children. In some instances this may be so, but the availability of child-care places and the imposition of a compulsory accreditation system are two quite different matters. One cannot be used to justify the other. If there are not enough child-care places, the solution is not the introduction of a bureaucratic national scheme of accreditation but the provision of more child-care places. As I have mentioned previously, that is a concern of the Queensland Creche and Kindergarten Association.

The answer is not to engage in an elaborate system of social engineering. I could quote no better person than former Labor senator Peter Walsh. He put this point very well in a speech he gave on the issue of accreditation just last month. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the critical issue is to make sure that this linkage to fee relief is broken.
Former Senator Walsh said this. He continued:

I mean, this is social engineering. The people who are designing this program, except the hidden agenda of course is to close the private sector down but the more obvious one is they do not believe that parents should be trusted to make their own decisions about what sort of child care they will have.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did Senator Walsh become an expert in child care?
—He is just as much one as Senator Margetts is. He went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The clear message is parents are not to be trusted and the state will decide what is good for them and the state will use, you know, the big stick of the denial of fee relief to make sure that parents make the decision they ought to make.

That came from the government side of the political fence. I know of others presently in the cabinet and caucus who would endorse his views. As Peter Walsh notes, the measurement of quality is an inherently subjective process. The difficulty of prescribing quality is reflected in the mishmash of the 52 principles that make up the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System Handbook. It is bureaucracy gone mad. There are other more nebulous concepts. They are not the worst aspects of the guidelines. These guidelines—this compulsory national system of accreditation—will lead to increased child-care costs and, by virtue of this, fewer children in formal care.

PARA.TAB: The minister has been running around suggesting that the increase will be only 88c per week per place, but this is based on costings included in a report to the previous minister which just about nobody has seen. The claim is totally false. The minister knew it was false when a letter was sent back to him in November 1992 stating that the Interim National Child Care Accreditation Council had told him that accreditation was—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have not spoken on this issue, although we are aware that it has been debated at length. We want to put on record our view on child-care accreditation. The Greens believe that it is high time there was child-care accreditation; that the quality of child care is more important than the quality of university education; and that standards are appropriate.

PARA.TAB: At this point in time, child-care centres represent a very valuable bridge between the family and the community. These centres can offset and assist a disadvantaged family where a child is an only child or from a different cultural grouping. Apart from regulations and licensing, the child-care system has had no uniform standards to focus on the quality of child care.

Recent publicity has focused on the involvement of children in violent crimes. My background involved working with people imprisoned for violent offences such as murder and sexual assault. We know that the factors that lead to these problems often arise from damage in childhood. Therefore, it is time our community took responsibility for the level of child care. I do not think anybody would disagree with this. I acknowledge that the opposition concurs that child care is so vitally important within our community that it deserves to be of the highest quality. The dispute is about the linkage between fee relief and accreditation and the fact that it is not a voluntary process but a compulsory one. Also, there are complaints about the government guidelines to implement quality control in child-care centres and complaints about parental or administrative intrusiveness into management. The Greens do not support a disallowance motion and do support the introduction of accreditation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking as a parent.

—No, not as a parent, but as a member of the community who is deeply concerned about what is happening. For long periods every day child-care centres are responsible for the developmental health of children who are in their care. The damage caused by poor quality child care is difficult to reverse and is unacceptable in the short and long term. I might add that the campaign against the accreditation system has descended to an absurd level by focusing on guidelines for Christmas carols and other issues.

PARA.TAB: I have looked at the 52 principles. Clearly, there is a self-assessment program and guidelines for its gradual introduction and parental involvement. There is nothing within those guidelines that an excellent child-care centre would not already be doing. Although there may be flaws in the way the principles are structured or documented, an excellent quality child-care system will be easily able to abide by those principles. And we are debating the principle of the quality of child care, not an editorial critique of a book that has been written to try to implement something to benefit our entire community.

Concerns have been expressed about the process followed in reaching the guiding principles, the evaluation of whether a centre meets required standards, whether the principles are achievable or desirable and possible unforeseen consequences. It is appropriate to have that debate. However, it is appropriate to introduce such standards. A decision has been reached amongst the Greens, following wide consultation, with people both supporting and opposing the system, in Western Australia and on the east coast, to support the government's child-care quality improvement and accreditation system as long as there is an undertaking to conduct a full review of the improved system before July 1995. We have been given the assurance that a review will be forthcoming.

The need for good quality child care and accountability for government funding means that we will not support the opposition motion of disallowance of ministerial guidelines. If the government is providing fee relief, it is appropriate that it look at its own accountability and make that accountability far broader than simply by regulation, staff numbers and licensing. The quality of care is the crucial area here and if the government is subsidising child care then it has a duty to ensure that it is not supporting inadequate child care.
I conclude by saying that we cannot avoid the issue of child care in our community. The absence of any accreditation system over the last number of years and the need to actually introduce something—
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Senator Kemp. It is not the slightest bit authoritarian. It allows self-assessment and peer review. That is perfectly acceptable and needs to be there for the protection of the children of our community as well as the parents who are forced to seek fee relief. It would be irresponsible of a government not to be moving in this direction. While there may be criticisms of the way in which it has been implemented, those concerns can be addressed and further refinement of the scheme can occur after consultations with all concerned.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important that the review that is going to be conducted by the government into the process, after it has been in operation for 12 months, should involve the elected National Childcare Accreditation Council or some other body with broad representation from all affected parties. However, I think that we do need a system and for that reason the Greens will be supporting the system, provided that the government undertakes to institute a review prior to July 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I willingly join in the debate on the disallowance motion moved by Senator Herron. We are discussing childhood. It is no longer a time of pedal cars, pop guns and mud pies. Under Labor it is a time of politically correct toys, politically correct food, politically correct activities, politically correct behaviour, politically correct staff, politically correct decor, politically correct language and politically correct songs. Thou shalt not do this; thou shalt not do that. Colours must not be too competitive, colouring-in books are bad because they are conformist, and staff must avoid using the words `no' and `naughty'. The list is endless.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, has gone to the mount of the government and trade union dominated child-care committee and returned weighed down with many tablets of stone to hang around the necks of the child-care centres. There are 52 principles and hundreds of commandments—and the government says it will cost 88c a week per child to implement.

The government admits that staffing arrangements have not been included in its costings because they are a matter for the states. Senator Crowley said that her costings have been backed up by a survey with a sample of one. I bet the Labor Party is glad Senator Crowley does not do its polling, although I must admit it would be cheap!

That is what the government's approach has been on this issue—cheap. It has nothing to do with money but a lot to do with the quality of government. The government has been too cheap to get the private child-care industry on side and too cheap in its private consultants cost analysis, which has so many holes in it that when its contents are sifted there is little of value left. The government has been too cheap to do a comprehensive and up-to-date costing. It would rather rely on the costing for a superseded model and pass it off as a new model. It has been too cheap to recognise the enormous cost on parents and child-care centres of its social experiment. It has been cheap with parents and with the private child-care industry but, most importantly, it has been cheap with the innocence and fragility of childhood.

The government has treated childhood as though it is an intricate disease that needs a specialist surgeon to monitor every aspect of the patient's progress. The government has imposed an ideological uniform on toddlers and it has levelled the kindergarten playing field to ensure that every aspect of everyone's childhood can be classified, stamped politically correct and filed away in triplicate.

There are two major features of this handbook which support a motion of disallowance. The first is the content of the principles themselves. The second is the cost that compliance with the principles will impose on child-care centres and parents around Australia.

I join with Senator Herron and make it quite clear that what is at issue here is not whether child-care centres must strive to give our children the best care possible, but how to encourage the child-care centres to do this. What, in the end, constitutes the best care possible? Obviously I think home care is the best care possible—a mother's care—but let us concede that there are some parents who cannot achieve that because of economic circumstances or other eventualities—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a father's care.

—Or a father's care. Should a government lay down such detailed guidelines with such open-ended qualifiers as are included in this handbook before the Senate? Will they not harass the caring process rather than enhance it? Should a government then enforce compliance with these hundreds of details with the threat of removing fee relief? There are so many trees in this handbook that it is impossible to see the forest.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley has delighted in rubbishing my colleagues when they sought only to relate what was in the handbook. The following are direct quotes from the handbook, and I defy Senator Crowley or anyone else in the Senate to say that they are not there. The handbook states that a child-care centre is unsatisfactory if staff make sex-biased remarks about appearance, such as `That is a pretty dress', or `You are a handsome young man'. Principle 3 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Staff provide stereotyped toys such as trains, tip trucks and bulldozers for boys, and dolls and tea-sets for girls.
Principle 7 states:
Staff use `no' and `naughty'. . .
Principle 7 further states:
Staff interrupt children's activities, expecting them to conform immediately to staff demands.
Principle 21 states:
There are stencils and colour-in activities, which do not foster creativity.
There is a constant repetition of Christmas songs as background at the end of the year.
It states that a child's care is only basic if:
. . . songs are only for special occasions such as Christmas and are culturally irrelevant for many children.

These are all written in the guidelines for everyone to see, and they affect whether a child-care centre will qualify for fee relief. Removing one or two of these guidelines will not fix the problem. The whole thrust of the handbook is calculated so as to control every aspect of child care from one particular point of view.Let me illustrate for Senator Crowley the extent of the control by quoting from principle 17. It states:

In order to plan sensitively and appropriately for each child, it is essential to keep written development records to which all staff can contribute. Detailed development records allow staff to set goals for each child, devise strategies to achieve the goals, keep track of the child's progress and plan appropriate experiences for further learning and development. Every week, staff should closely observe some children during different activities and make a record of their level of development. Useful methods of recording observations include:
.a diary of incidental and anecdotal record (that is, descriptions of particular incidents or events and of general behaviour);
.an individual development log, divided into development areas such as physical, intellectual, social/emotional and language;
.a development checklist, listing skills that can be expected of a child of a particular age. . . .
The learning experience planned for individual children should be incorporated into the program for the whole group.

One would think we are talking about a postgraduate program for elite Olympic athletes, not infants, toddlers and preschoolers. Why not make them wear brown shirts and send them all to kindy and be done with it, Senator Crowley? This is cradle to the grave type indoctrination, and close personal monitoring that would not be tolerated even in North Korea. What next, Madam Acting Deputy President? If child-care fee relief is tied to compliance with such regimes, what will the family allowance be tied to in the future? That is something we should all consider.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the costs. The second feature of the handbook that marks it for disallowance is that the government says these 51 principles and their hundreds of sub-commandments will cost a child-care centre 88c a week per child. This is based on a costing analysis of an earlier handbook. The consultants came up with a cost of $44 per child for a seven-week pilot study. They simply assumed then that the seven-week pilot program on which these costings were based was equivalent to a first year in an ongoing program. So they spread the $44 cost over 50 weeks and came up with a figure of 88c per child per week. However, ongoing costs, such as the need to provide consistency of care, which involves employing additional staff on an ongoing basis, could not have been included in the government costings.

The minister said that the guideline accreditation process was pilot tested in a large number of centres, by which she meant 32 out of 2,265 centres, or 1.4 per cent of the population. Senator Crowley's consultants acknowledged that the conclusions which can be drawn from the surveys are limited by the very small sample. So that admission was made by the minister's own consultants. There was no audit of responses. Four so-called extreme cases were excluded from the costings of unpaid time. Therefore, 12.5 per cent of the centres surveyed were left out of the costings because they did not fit into the expected parameters. That is not a rigorous methodology and casts further doubt on the credibility of the final results.
I would like to remind the Senate of the previous minister's election promise, made three days before the election to private child-care centres, in a letter dated 10 March 1993. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: No service will need to be required to put on new staff, increase qualified staff, buy new equipment or in any other way incur costs because of accreditation.

I have asked the current minister, Senator Crowley, to give a guarantee that the 1992 costings of 88c a week per child are comprehensive and accurate, given that they were based on a different handbook from that which is currently before the Senate, and they were drawn from an unaudited seven-week pilot study of 1.4 per cent of child-care centres. Senator Crowley has not been forthcoming with that guarantee, and I believe it is not likely that I will get it. There are significant differences between the two handbooks. Principle 51 in the current book specifically states:
Where several staff members work together, each of them should care particularly for an agreed group of children, so that each child receives consistent care from only one or two staff members.
Previously, the study had this restriction only for infants. Applying such staffing restrictions to all children regardless of age places a greater staffing cost on child-care centres.
The government and the private child-care industry have both done independent costings on aspects of the child-care accreditation system, which I seek leave to table.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those costings have come up with vastly different results. The government claims it would cost 88c a week per child, while the private child-care industry claims costs would increase by $30 to $69 a week. This is due to new expenditure on primary contact staff, contract staff, direct operational costs and other indirect overheads and capital costs. Due to these large discrepancies, and due to the need to reassure parents and the private sector, I asked the minister last night privately—and I do so now in the Senate—whether she would consent to appointing a professional mediator, perhaps someone from Coopers and Lybrand, to bring the two sides together and work through their differences in order to arrive at common ground. Only then, after she has done that, can she tell the Senate that she has done her best to provide a facility that would get the two sides together. To date, she has not done that. I await her response to that call when she makes her contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: I would like to raise one final point which the minister might clarify. In answer to my question earlier this week about the government's costings and why they were at such odds with the private sector's independent costings the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The private child-care sector and the opposition must appreciate that the staffing arrangements are not included in these figures to any large extent. The relief staff for the accreditation process is incorporated but the staffing arrangement Senator Boswell is talking to is a matter for states and properly does not belong in the accreditation figuring.

Surely, it is nonsense to say that these accreditation guidelines do not impact on staffing because staffing is a state matter. If a child-care centre wants to qualify for fee relief, it must meet the federal government guidelines, which will require greater staff expenditure. Principle 51 has significant implications for staffing levels which would send child-care costs soaring when applied to all age groups and not just to infants, as was the case in the earlier handbook. The Association of Child Care Centres in New South Wales commissioned, at considerable expense, an independent costing analysis of the quality improvement and accreditation system handbook. Those are the figures which I have tabled. They remain the only up-to-date and comprehensive costings in existence. They show that child-care costs would rise by $30 to $69 per child per week. Contrary to the minister's claims in the Senate the other day, the association has stated:

. . . the handbook has a substantial impact on staffing levels, rosters and expenditure. The private child care sector has not been adequately consulted about the accreditation system. How can we have been when we have only three voices out of 17 on the interim national accreditation council and only two out of 9 on the National Child Care Accreditation Council? The two honourable women chosen for their expertise in private child care have resigned from the NCAC due in part to the misrepresentation on behalf of the government. We and the parents of children we care for are extremely concerned that the costs of implementing all of these open-ended guidelines will rob parents of their freedom of choice and promote elitist child care.

That is a ringing disendorsement of Senator Crowley's accreditation plans. Senator Crowley must get an independent arbitrator to bring these two sides together. If she does not do this, she is putting a wedge between the child-care organisations and she is not being fair and honest. I call on Senator Crowley to appoint an independent arbitrator to examine the government's costings and those of the independent child-care centres. Someone must be wrong and someone must be right, or there must be some middle ground. I say to Senator Crowley that, if she is right, I will apologise to her in the Senate. If she is wrong, I would expect her to apologise to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to begin where Senator Boswell left off, because this whole issue of costings, I believe, has been misconstrued and, indeed, misunderstood. What these guidelines are doing is saying what the existing staff should be doing if they are going to provide good quality child care.

PARA.TAB: The states do have their regulations, and set out in those regulations are various formulae and various requirements with regard to staff. We need more than just straight numbers of people on the ground if we are going to have good quality child care. We have to look at what staff are doing, what the children are doing—indeed, what the toddlers and infants are doing—during the day. So these guidelines are not saying, `You have to appoint X, Y or Z extra staff'. They are saying, `The existing staff, who by state regulations already have to be there, should be involved as follows'.

All I can suggest is that some people perhaps have not been following their state guidelines. Perhaps we might find some centres out there that will have to look at staffing because they have been finding ways around the current staffing formulas. I am told it is possible to do that in one state. I leave that up to those child-care workers.

I stress here that it is not the department that will be looking at how all this fits together and at how the centres are operating; it will be child-care workers who will go out and look at each other's centres. The centres themselves initially will have to have done their own reviews.

I think the whole problem of costings will gradually work itself through. As we are partly debating the reference of this issue to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I do not see how it will be possible for that committee to have either the resources or the time before 1 February to move around the countryside and check up on the state guidelines, asking people whether each centre is abiding by this or that state guideline, firstly, regarding the number of staff they are supposed to have on duty at any one time and, secondly, regarding the qualifications that that staff is supposed to hold.

The issue of costings obviously will be very controversial. It will continue to simmer until the middle of next year when centres will begin—putting aside the hype, which I will deal with in a moment—to look realistically at what is in these guidelines and realise that they are probably following them already.

That brings me back to the process. This document was not drawn up in the back rooms of the department somewhere; it was prepared by the child-care people themselves. While some of us, including me, may have phrased it in another way and may not have gone to such lengths to set out options and to make fairly clear and succinct statements, that is not the way those people chose to do it. Surely we would be in as much trouble now if we said, `Oh, the minister has had a go at this and rephrased it all'. This is the phrasing and terminology that child-care workers are used to and what they feel comfortable with.

This brings me to the inconsistencies. The opposition says, `Yes, quality child care is wonderful; it is just that no-one is allowed to check up to see if it is happening'. The opposition is saying to parents, `You have to live with the quality of child care that you have. We think it should be good child care, but we will not give you any assistance as to what that child care should involve. We aren't going to help you at all'.

Such nonsense as cutting out Christmas—which I will deal with in a moment—is what parents are having great difficulty coping with. Of course parents are confused, thanks to the National Party, about what exactly is going on. Many of them are contacting their child-care centres, and hopefully those centres are giving them a look at this document—giving it to them to take away and to go through. When that happens, people realise that a lot of nonsense is being talked about by the opposition.

Turning now to the guidelines, I start with principle 3 which Senator Boswell referred to earlier. Instead of selectively quoting, I will go through the process of looking at what is unsatisfactory, the basic requirements, good quality and high quality on the issue of toys. In principle 3 it says that it is unsatisfactory if:

SPEECH.PARA: Staff provide stereotyped toys such as trains, tip trucks and bulldozers for boys, and dolls and tea-sets for girls.
Under basic quality, it says:
Staff attempt to minimise sex differences in some areas but may show bias in subtle ways.

In other words, we are saying to those people who have never had any dealings with young children that toys are put in a container, in a box, in a corner and children are actually able to choose for themselves whether they play with bulldozers or dolls. Boys are not confined—

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney, it is a long time since you watched children play.
—I have six children.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Tierney and Senator Crowley, would you both come to order, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that the opposition really does not want to hear what is in this document. These guidelines are saying that we do not restrict boys to playing with one type of toy; nor do we restrict girls to playing only with one type of toy. The toys are there for collective use and no directions are placed on children as to what is appropriate or inappropriate.I will continue to read the guidelines under `Good quality'. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: Staff consistently provide equal opportunities for boys and girls to participate in all activities, play with all materials, play vigorously on outdoor equipment, express a range of emotions and contribute to discussion.

In other words, there are no barriers determined by staff as to what is the appropriate toy for you or what is the appropriate toy for somebody else. Now we get to principle 7, which was also discussed earlier today, on the question of saying no. Let us look at the age group we are talking about. It says it is unsatisfactory in relation to infants as follows:
Staff use `no' and `naughty' often, especially when children's interests conflict with staff's needs to accomplish routine activities quickly.
I stress that we are talking about infants—not toddlers or preschoolers. Let us look at the basic requirement:
Staff allow some opportunities for exploration and early independence; e.g. let a child hold one spoon while they use another to feed.
Staff use playpens for brief periods only (if at all).
Staff remain patient with children who remove clothes and resist dressing.
To go on to what is good quality for infants—and again I stress this is for infants—under principle 7:
Staff provide carefully supervised, safe opportunities for children to explore their environment with their mouths and hands, and more actively when they are able to crawl.
Staff allow children to hold spoons and make some attempts to feed themselves, when they show this desire.
In other words, normal processes of development are encouraged. High quality includes the following:
Staff are very sensitive to the varying levels of competence of children and know when to offer choice and when not to, when to offer help and when to withhold it.
Now I come to Christmas. Let us look at what is unsatisfactory in principle 21:
The only music children hear is taped music that meets staff preferences. This is on for a large part of the day.
The second comment under `Unsatisfactory' with regard to music is:
There are no musical instruments for the children to play and they learn no songs.
Under `Basic', it says:
The program provides some music specifically for children—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what it says. Read the guidelines.
—Obviously Senator Kemp has not read the guidelines, because that is a basic requirement. The basic requirement is:

SPEECH.PARA: Children learn songs—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am a little bit worried, as we are going through these guidelines, that we seem to be missing some of the guidelines which are the substance of the debate. I do not know whether this is on purpose or whether Senator Lees is not able to read clearly.
—Senator Kemp, what is your point of order?
—The point of order is one of relevance, that we tackle the issues which are controversial, and we seem to be missing them as we read through it.
—I find the point of order very hard to sustain. I would appreciate it if senators on my left would cease interjecting because, if they do not, they will have no time to make their own contributions.

—I am reading all principles specifically to do with the misrepresentation that has been going on. There is no mention of Christmas in the `Unsatisfactory' section, and I was about to get to it when Senator Kemp interrupted me.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Following Senator Kemp's point on relevance, under principle 21, `Unsatisfactory', there is a very clear remark about Christmas. I draw that to the attention of Senator Lees and ask her to go back to the `Unsatisfactory' column and read it out, otherwise nothing of substance will be added to this debate.
—There is no point of order. Senator McGauran, you will have your opportunity in the future.
—I am reading the top section under each of the headings.
—Read the Christmas carols.
—I am about to. Under `Basic' it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Children learn songs but the repertoire is not large, or songs are only for special occasions such as Christmas and are culturally irrelevant for many children.

That is a basic requirement. In other words, there is no problem with playing Christmas carols and only Christmas carols at Christmas, but that is not sufficient for the opposition. The next section, which concerns music, states:
Children hear and learn simple finger plays and songs . . . The program gives children the opportunity to hear music with simple strong rhythms, and they are encouraged to move freely to the music.
This is for good quality. It goes on:
There are musical instruments such as xylophones, drums, tambourines and shakers. Home-made instruments are also used a lot.
The guidelines on high quality state:

The program emphasises a wide variety of areas for creative expression, and children are brought into contact with the creativity of others through visits from musicians, artists, dancers, puppeteers and drama groups.

The program includes many creative experiences and exposes children to the music, songs and artistic forms of expression of varying cultural groups, including the music, dance and art of the Australian Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders . . . There is a sense of enthusiasm as children experiment in various forms of creative expression.

So what we are saying is that there is not just a constant repetition of Christmas songs being played in the background somewhere. We are saying that, as part of a program, children learn the songs—that is a basic requirement—but a lot of other things are added on; for example, opportunities for children to experiment with musical instruments.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Christmas?

—Maybe not at Christmas; it does not ask children to do, at Christmas, any other particular activity. But it does say that children need to participate and not just be treated as objects, with music on in the background. One other area that there has been considerable misrepresentation about—and it was mentioned by Senator Boswell today—is children not being allowed to have stencils and colouring-in books. Again, that is absolute nonsense. I quote again from the `unsatisfactory' section of the guidelines:

SPEECH.PARA: Any books provided are poorly or inadequately illustrated.
Any art materials used tend to emphasise conformity rather than creativity . . .
We are talking about when there are no art materials other than just stencils and colouring-in books. The guidelines on basic requirements say:
There are some art activities such as painting or finger painting, but few experiences with other materials.
The guidelines on the good quality level say:
There is a wide variety of art materials such as clay, dough, bark, fabric pieces, recycled `junk', chalk, crayon . . .

In other words, there are not just colouring-in books and nothing else. Kids will get to participate in a wide variety of options from time to time. At some stages it may be appropriate, with a few minutes left before mum or dad picks them up, that they have only a colouring-in book. But that is not the be-all and end-all as far as any artistic expression is concerned. It means that during the day they will have had an opportunity to experiment with something else. Let us get back to what this motion is really about. This motion is saying that we cannot just sit kids down for the day and expect them to amuse themselves in a corner.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—No-one is saying that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are hearing is very close to that. What we are saying here is that there is a range of options and experiences that young children—and remember that we are starting with infants, moving to toddlers and then up to those who are getting ready for preschool—should be experiencing when they are left in care. Let us look at the number of hours that those children are in care. We are talking about a 40-hour week for many children—in some cases it is longer than that if parents have considerable distances to travel. We are talking about making sure that those children are experiencing something of value.

PARA.TAB: I really have to ask some of those private child-care centres who are kicking up so much fuss, `What do you have to hide? What are your children doing now?'. It should not be expensive to implement what is in this book. It is very inexpensive to get recycled materials, for example, and make them into simple toys that children can rattle, shake or tap in time with music. It is very inexpensive to find some Christmas carols that the kids can sing along to, rather than just have Christmas carols on in the background as background noise. Surely staff in those centres, if they are trained—and this comes back to whether or not people actually know what the state guidelines are and are following them—will have no problems with what is in this book. If parents are actually given a chance to read what is in here, then I believe parents will not have a great amount of difficulty either.

In my state of South Australia, I will make a point next year of visiting a number of child-care centres. I know that at least three are concerned about these guidelines. I will work through the guidelines with them and certainly make every effort to ease the threats being felt by these centres. It is very important that everybody be involved cooperatively—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about parents who feel frightened by them?

—We are talking about parents; we are talking about those people who work in the centres; and, of course, we are talking about those people who own the centres. It should not be threatening for people to simply sit back and look at what we are asking, which is that children have worthwhile experiences for the bulk of their day when they are awake and active.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit difficult to know exactly how to shape this debate on the motions concerning child-care guidelines.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. It is normal practice, if the minister wishes to respond, that she respond at the end of the debate, not in the middle. It is logical to assume that there are a few more speakers on this side, and it seems to me that it would be better if Senator Crowley could contain her enthusiasm and wait until she has heard all of the arguments.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—The minister can speak whenever she wishes, because it is an opposition motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, excuse me if I cut across, but if I could have a clear indication from the opposition as to how many speakers there are and when it intends to conclude this debate, allowing time for me to speak, I would be more than pleased to do that. But I have been provided with no clear indication of what might be the limit of this debate, and it is a little difficult to cooperate with the opposition. If the opposition can give me an assurance that before a quarter to one today, or whenever this debate can be concluded, I will have my half hour to speak, I will be very pleased to speak at that time. If it cannot, then I think it might be appropriate for me to make my comments refuting claims to this point.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order to respond to that statement. Of course, I have no authority to respond—
—Why are you doing it?

—It seems to me that this is the best way to do it. I have a constructive suggestion, which may be of interest to Senator Burns. It would be better if he went back to the Time that he was reading and left the debate to those of us who are interested in it. I think it may assist if the whips could consult on this matter so, if there is a need to bring the debate to an end at a certain time, a time can be fixed taking into account the wishes of honourable senators who wish to participate.

—As I cannot get any assurance on when the debate will end, I shall proceed to make my comments now. I believe it is important that we contribute to the debate at this stage. It has been a little difficult to decide how to refute Senator Herron's claims. Many of his claims were quite wrong. It is very disappointing that the mover of this motion can be so wrong, for example, in his understanding about what state licensing regulations do.
—Stop drawing red herrings.

—It is not a red herring; it is a very smelly fish, and it has a very relevant smell to this opposition campaign. I have said before to Senator Boswell—and he suggested in his comments that I was not telling the truth about staff—and I indicate again to him that he does not have it right. Let me just explain so that this matter is beyond confusion. There are state licensing regulations in most states and territories which all centres must pass before they can open. State licensing regulations apply well before anything to do with accreditation happens. State licensing regulations determine the number of staff, particularly the number of staff compared to the number of students. They have nothing to do with accreditation; they have everything to do with state regulations. Our accreditation guidelines do not address them.

PARA.TAB: I hope that is clearly understood by the opposition. What is more, the state government has its own group of people who go around and make sure that those licences are being complied with. All of the terrible things that the opposition accuses this government of doing have been happening in the child-care area for years at the state level, and no child-care centre has raised a major protest about it. They understand those state licensing regulations.

If I have put that too strongly, I accept that that might be a misinterpretation on my part. I do not believe so. Let me make it clear that the state regulations govern staff and that those centres have to be inspected from time to time to make sure they are complying. Those regulations are in place at the moment. All private and community based child-care centres conform to them. When they do not they are penalised. But that has nothing to do with accreditation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just another layer of bureaucracy.

—Again, Senator Herron indicates, through his words, his misunderstanding of what accreditation is about. Another statement that Senator Herron made that I would like to refute very early on, and I do not know why he threw it in because it is a disappointment when Senator Herron grabs six straws by way of refuting this, is that this is a secret plot—I think he said secret, but he may have just said a plot—by the government to close down private child-care centres. Senator Herron has to know that is a nonsense. It disappoints me that a man of his standing would actually be bothered with saying such nonsense here or anywhere else.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron and I have worked on committees and we have a fair understanding of who we are. I do not find it consistent with what I know about Senator Herron that he would say things such as this government has a plot, secret or otherwise, to close down private centres. I will tell him why. Firstly, we have actually extended child-care assistance or fee relief to the private child-care sector. That is an extraordinary extension by this government, and that is where the major growth in government outlays comes from. It is quite inconsistent to extend the child-care assistance or fee relief to the private sector one day and then say, `But we did not really mean it'. That is such a nonsense. I assure those opposite and anybody listening that the government welcomes the assistance of the private child-care centres in providing child-care places to meet the huge demand still out there.

Secondly, in this last budget we have extended special supplementary assistance to the private child-care centres. They had an allocation for 12 months. They now have an allocation for a further two years, which actually extends to the private child-care centre special assistance to help children with disabilities, children from non-English speaking backgrounds and children from Aboriginal communities or other isolated or disadvantaged areas.

A government does not extend that kind of support to the private sector if it is about to close down the child-care centres. Indeed, the government is doing exactly the opposite. It is so willing to work in cooperation with the private sector that there is an indication of it. We do not confine that special assistance money to the community based. We have now just extended it to the private centres, not for the first time but with an extension on the amount of money and the commitment: a one-year pilot has now become a two-year funding through the budget.

Thirdly, we have just extended sales tax exemption to private child-care centres. It goes to other child-care centres too, but it goes specifically to private child-care centres. We have fought—I have fought—to get that sales tax exemption through. We have had the inconsistency where preschools and kindergartens have had eligibility for sales tax exemption and child-care centres have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Senator West's posture and ask her to show some dignity.
—I take your point of order, but that matter has been rectified.
—I was explaining to the Senate, so as to allay any confusion from Senator Herron or concern amongst private centres that there is a plot to close them down, that we have just extended—

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: it was former Senator Peter Walsh. Senator Crowley goes on about some supposed statement that I made which I did not make. It was former Senator Peter Walsh. So she ought to talk to her adviser and find out.
—Senator Herron, are you claiming to be misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Crowley has been misrepresenting me for the last five minutes. I took it for a while because I did not want to interrupt the debate.
—Senator Herron, I believe you will have an opportunity to bring those matters to the minister's attention at the conclusion of the debate.

—I ascribed those remarks to Senator Herron because I heard him say them. If he was quoting Mr Peter Walsh, that is a different statement. I am glad to have the opportunity to refute it because it is certainly widely said by the private sector and was certainly put very strongly to me that they have it wrong.
—Former Senator Walsh.

—No, I am not saying anything about Senator Walsh. At a very significant and very large meeting in Melbourne last week which I attended the private child-care centres made the same point very strenuously. They said that this is a secret plot to close our private child-care centres. If I am not refuting it to Senator Herron, I am pleased that that is the case, but I am certainly refuting it because it is widely understood that it has been claimed that we are trying to close our private child-care centres. We have extended child-care assistance or fee relief to the private sector, we have extended the sales tax exemption to the private child-care centres and we have now extended the special supplementary assistance to the private child-care centres. They are three very good examples of government's continuous commitment to extending the range of services and to involving private and community based child-care centres in a network and cooperative partnership. In case my time should expire soon, I wish to read out a letter. It comes from the Next Generation Child Care Services Pty Ltd and reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Crowley,

. . . I am writing to you to express my support for your position on the introduction of the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System and its linkage to Childcare Assistance funding. In doing so, I hope this gives you some indication that groups such as the Association of Child Care Centres of NSW (of which I am a member) and individuals with vested interests who are choosing to `bury their heads in the sand' are not completely representative of the views of private child care operators. Like yourself, I am appalled at the nature of the criticism being levelled at you, your department and the NCAC.
The letter goes on to say:

I cannot accept the paranoid argument of some people, that the establishment of the NCAC and the introduction of the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System is a plot, influenced heavily by the unions, to remove private child care centres thereby dismantling the private child care industry, and returning the responsibility for the provision of all centre-based child care to the government and community-based organisations. No rational and objective consideration of the situation would support that point of view. Given the complexities of government child care funding I consider it totally reasonable that Childcare Assistance should be linked to accreditation. It is a fair and reasonable means of accountability.

The writer of the letter goes on to set out the work he has been doing to transform his child-care centre from that which it was previously—more a child minding centre than a child-care centre. The letter finishes:

We are fully committed to the accreditation process. Indeed, the spirit of the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System is reflected in our philosophy. I am an active member of the Association of Child Care Centres of NSW and I admire the executive for their hard work. However, I wish to distance myself from their stance on this issue.
Neil D. Brodie
Managing Director.

I can certainly read many letters. I have copies of the letters that honourable senators opposite have. Their figure was 21,000 at the last count. Ours is that and rising dramatically—indeed, it is much higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table them.

—I will not waste the Senate's time with that. I do not know whether those opposite have received all the supportive letters. Have they received all the supportive letters? Are they not perhaps coming in here and refusing to read them? Just in case that is the case, I will read one of them. This letter comes from the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry—VECCI. It reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: VECCI is the largest and most influential employer association and represents a large group of children's services centres in Victoria. We write on behalf of our numerous members in the private childcare proprietors, local government sector and community managed services who wish you to be aware of their overwhelming support for and endorsement of the accreditation system.

VECCI also represents companies that provide work based childcare services and these companies indicate support for quality assurance across their whole company and an expectation of a quality childcare service is just part of their overall philosophy and good management.
I would be pleased if you could convey these positive sentiments to your colleagues as they consider this important issue.
Yours Sincerely,
Mary-Jo Adams
Senior Employees Relations Consultant.
that would no doubt impress Senator Herron and other honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not be selectively quoting, would you?
—No. This is an article entitled `Child care wars' by Margaret Keneally in the Telegraph Mirror of 29 November. The last two paragraphs of this newspaper article state:

PARA.TAB: Some in the child care industry see the row as a lost opportunity. "The principles are mostly fine," said Bernadette Gianbaza who resigned in protest from the Accreditation Council.
"There's nothing wrong with them but accreditation should be voluntary. It's just very sad because we do need accreditation—we could have had a really good process out of this."

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is about the guidelines.

—I am very glad Senator Tierney says that. I will tell him what it is about. He keeps insisting that when Senator Lees reads out the guidelines, she has to be howled down. Does Senator Tierney want a debate about the guidelines? Does he want a debate about every spurious little red herring that the opposition has brought in here? Does he want a debate about the issues that are of concern in the community? I will give them to him. Geraldine Walsh, Letters Editor, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 December, said:

SPEECH.PARA: First prize for Hysteria Topic of the week went to child-care accreditation. Someone did an excellent job distorting general, caring and commonsense statements contained in the 107-page handbook, Putting Children First into a series of ridiculous prohibitions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. When a minister joins in a debate, she normally refutes the arguments put by the other side. Senator Crowley is so devoid of argument that she has fallen to reading articles out of a paper. Everyone on this side of the chamber and probably the other side—although that would be doubtful in some cases—is capable of reading articles out of the paper and reading letters. I am asking Senator Crowley, in the interests of a good debate, to debate the issues and—
—Senator Boswell, there is no point of order, and you know there is no point of order.
—There should be.
—The minister can use any material she wishes.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a matter of relevance. I think it would help the debate if I asked the minister to table the lengthy letters she is reading out verbatim and to get on with discussing the handbook.
—As I said earlier, that is no point of order. The minister may do as she wishes in the time available. I would ask her to continue.

—Goodness, gracious me! Those opposite raise the points, we refute them and they say, `Raise something else'. Points about state guidelines, when clearly explained and refuted and put to the opposition in a clear and understanding way, seem not to be points of refutation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney may shout, but in my own good time and in my own way I will address the issues. It is interesting that the opposition keeps saying, `We support accreditation, but we want a voluntary one'. That is clearly what I have quoted Senator Newman as saying. I never misrepresented her. She said—those opposite have all agreed; indeed others have been saying it today—`We support accreditation but we want it to be voluntary'. That is right. Members of the opposition need to understand what they are saying when they say that. What that means is that they will implement the guidelines and they do not want that associated with fee relief. Let us be clear what it means when they say they support the accreditation. They actually agree to accreditation voluntarily. The definition of an accredited centre at this stage involves implementing those guidelines, a description from the industry of what constitutes good practice or best practice.
—How many parents were involved?

—When those opposite say those things about the guidelines, they do not understand what they are saying. Accreditation is not a mark on a piece of paper. Accreditation is a process where the staff and the parents of the centre work through that book for however long it takes to reach a satisfactory standard or beyond. It is not a case of, `Right now you'll be measured'—it has never been that. It is a process of using those guidelines as guidance to improve if they need to or to satisfy themselves that they are already providing quality child care. Many people in the private industry welcome it because it is giving them some kind of benchmark. `How do we know we're giving good child care?', they ask. `Thank goodness for those guidelines'.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite may argue about the guidelines, but they are not made up by the government. As Senator Lees said, if I or the department had made up these guidelines, those opposite would have a better case for their howling—but we did not. Senator Lees said that she would like to rewrite some of the words. I have already said that. Certainly I could have expressed it differently, but they are its guidelines, not ours. In using the guidelines—not dictatorial requirements—the industry, both community based and private, is assisted in knowing what constitutes accreditation. What do opposition senators mean by accreditation if it is not those guidelines? Is it something else that they will describe? Is it something else that they will make up? It was piloted in 16 community based centres and 14 private centres. In every one of those centres, parents were involved in the process because that is how it is done.

Senator Herron got another point wrong. There is a parent representative on the NCAC at the moment. I do not want to go into it because those opposite do not want to hear it. It might comfort and console those opposite more to know that those 16 community based and 14 private centres that went through the process, against which the only valid costing has been done—it was done against the process as it happened, not from reading the guidelines and making guesses—and it is valid to the extent that it can be assessed at this point, clearly said, `We appreciate that this is a small sample'. It represented 16 community based and 14 private centres.

All those centres reported that it was a very constructive and satisfactory process for them to go through. They learned a lot. They enjoyed discovering what constituted the practice in their child-care centre. Every centre found that it did not have to increase its staff at all, which is not a requirement of the accreditation. The accreditation process is not a staffing one, it is a state licensing matter. Those opposite do not want to hear about this. The report back from those centres is that it is a very constructive process. What makes me most disappointed in this whole thing is that so many parents have been needlessly agitated. All the parents who have seen the guidelines and have gone through the centres and through the process find it absolutely enjoyable and constructive.

Let me make clear what these guidelines say. There are no bans in any of the guidelines. There are descriptions of alternative things to do. Senator Lees has taken us through three of them and we could do that with every one of them. I have given an assurance that I will take direct action if I hear of any centre banning anything. There are no bans. There is a description of alternative things to do that give children an enjoyable, varied and constructive day. It is a long time since some of those opposite have put their noses around the door of a child-care centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't bet.

—I said some of those opposite. If they did, they would know what Senator Lees, Senator Chamarette and I—in fact, anyone supporting it—have been saying. We need to know what children do in child-care centres.

PARA.TAB: The example of Senator Lees of a box of toys is splendid. There could be a box of music, a box of toys, a box of alternative foods—anything. For the troops opposite, I say that as a metaphor. I am not suggesting food in boxes; I am suggesting that we give children choice. When children are given a choice, little girls may choose trains and little boys may choose dolls. Does Senator Tierney not believe that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll tell you a little story about that.
—I am sure Senator Tierney may prove a point on the case of one person, or his family. I am saying those opposite should look at what child-care centres do.
—Feminist.
—Senator Tierney is funny. The other day I visited a child-care centre. I visit a lot of them.
—So?
—I ask Senator Tierney not to be rude and not to put himself down like that.
—I am putting you down. You don't know what you are doing.

—Senator Tierney's suggestion that I do not know about child-care centres is pretty silly stuff from a person like him. I have visited many child-care centres. When I popped in the other day—it may shock him to discover this—I saw two little girls happily playing trains.
—So?

—So it is a matter of celebration. The honourable senator was suggesting a minute ago that the opposite was the case. I want to take up one very important issue that the opposition has raised. This debate has collapsed two motions. The first is a reference for the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs to look at the costing. In opposing that reference, I want to say that there is no way that the accreditation process can be properly costed unless it is in the process of being implemented.
—What an admission!
—No, that is exactly what we have said all along. I have said it already today; I have said it before.
—You said 88c.

—Exactly; on the process of it being evaluated. All the other evaluations are taking best guesses, heroic assumptions or amazing calculations, based on the guidelines. It can only be done on the process as it happens. Nothing of that process effectively will have been happening in the time Senator Herron asked about. Senator Lees and I spoke extensively to Senator Herron yesterday. He did not want to take the sensible amendment to refer to this again in six months time. In six months time many centres will have started the accreditation process—or completed it—and there will be real live data on which the costing can be based.

PARA.TAB: It will be for the private centres as much as those that are community based. It will not be a rigged ballot, or any of those things. It will be seriously based on the experience of accreditation. I am quite sure the person whose letter I read out would be delighted to have the accreditation process and the assessment of costs going through his centre. I know that many people from the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which covers many private centres as well as many community based centres—those people support accreditation and its link with fee relief—would be happy to be part of that analysis. We will have to look into the process.
