TALK.START.PARA: —I will be fairly brief because time is running out on this debate after that very longwinded contribution from the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). The minister gave the game away—this will be the theme of my comments. If a centre bans something, the minister will be there and she will fix it. I do not know whether Australians want a minister to have that sort of power over child care. It goes to the nub of what I wish to say. There is considerable tension about these guidelines, which explains the concern parents have. A lot of press comment has related to the authoritarian nature of the guidelines.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walsh, in his column in the Australian Financial Review—a good old, longstanding Labor man, not a supporter of our side by any stretch of the imagination—said that the most obnoxious thing about the guidelines is the pervasive authoritarianism. That is why I referred to the minister's comments. Whether or not people know what is good for them, the Interim National Accreditation Council will see they get it—whether they like it or not.

As the minister and a number of other speakers, including Senator Lees, have said, there is very widespread concern amongst parents about these guidelines. It is true, as Senator Lees said, that probably the vast number of those have not had the opportunity to read the guidelines. What has come through to a lot of parents is a feeling that child-care specialists and the government are starting to impose something on them. Naturally, they are starting to express that concern.

I am a parent who has had children in child-care arrangements and who has taken an interest in these things. Perhaps the key point which should have been expressed in the documents we have before us is that parental values are the most important ones. The values of the parents, which parents do their best to impart—taking into account the good care of children—are the values which have to predominate. In our free society, which is made up of very diverse groups, parents wish to bring up their children in a variety of ways. Any sensible, structured child-care arrangements will reflect that diversity of values in this community. Hence, when we start to impose guidelines which are as prescriptive as these we start to bump into those key values.

Of course, there are child-care centres which cater for Moslem children and, as somebody pointed out to me today, Jewish children. Those child-care centres will want to reflect the values of the parents. There are many parents who, broadly defined, I would say have fairly traditional views on how children should be brought up. They are happy to see their daughters playing with dolls and their sons playing with trucks. They never feel any fear or concern when their children come home and sing Christmas carols. In fact, they take great pleasure in it; just as I have in going to a child-care centre to see my daughter in a Christmas play. The problem lies with the authoritarian nature of these guidelines, and that is what parents are objecting to.

Many Labor senators have what I would describe as pretty trendy views about child care. I am happy for their respective child-care centres to reflect their views. I do not want to intrude into how their children are brought up. But, equally, I do not want those opposite to intrude into how I want my children and grandchildren brought up. We are an increasingly educated, free and tolerant society. Therefore, in that sort of society there will be a diversity of views. It is that diversity which we genuinely have to cater for in child-care arrangements.

The people who drew up these guidelines were aware of this problem. I draw the attention of the minister to principles 16, 31 and 48. Each of those, in varying ways, tries to tackle this problem of parental values versus the values of the child-care experts. For example, the introduction says that staff should consult with parents when there may be a conflict between the centre's philosophy and family values. Other guidelines say that the philosophy of the centre has to be worked out between the values of the parents and the values of the child-care providers.

I am certainly not opposed to consultation. I have met many people with long experience and expertise in the child-care area whose advice I have been more than comfortable in accepting. But, at the end of the day, there will be serious conflict between the values of the parents and the values of the child-care providers at a particular centre in relation to quite a few issues.

The minister should have been able to say to Australian parents, `It is your values which are the important values in child care. To the extent we are able, we will encourage child-care arrangements to reflect your values. Child-care providers are there to assist in providing the expertise, experience and advice. But, in the end, they are your children and it is you who must have the final say'. If that had been expressed in a clear, unequivocal way in this document—I do not say there is not an attempt to do that on one or two pages, but it is a very equivocal approach—the minister would have had none of this angst from the community.

The community is right to be wary of any authoritarian attempts by government to impose a set of views and a set of values. In the end, we on this side trust the people; we trust the parents. It is our job to make sure that their values predominate. That is the difference between the government and the opposition. I do not deny that those opposite have spoken to people. Senator Zakharov was kind enough to tell me that, in her experience, there had been a degree of consultation with parents.

But the bottom line is that the government came down on the side of what I would have thought were some fairly trendy views on bringing up children. The government has incorporated those views in the guidelines. That is why parents are getting upset. Australians today will not be dictated to by governments or by experts—child-care experts or any other type. We are an intelligent, proud people. We know what we want for our children. It is the government's job to reflect our values, not to impose its values on parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up one point in the debate before expressing a view in relation to the possible reference of the matter to a committee. Parents do have access—and are guaranteed the ability to have access—to the accreditation process. The opposition has expressed the great desire that parents should be part of, and have a say in, the way that their children are brought up, including the kind of care that they receive. That is a very important principle and a very important part of the accreditation process. That seems to be what a minority of child-care centres are concerned about because they do not necessarily want parental access to their processes. If we want to make sure that parents do play a part in the process and in the type and nature of child care, the accreditation process is one way of doing that.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the Greens do not support the motion of disallowance in relation to the accreditation process, we will be willing to support a reference to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, provided it is not required to report by 1 February 1994. We do not have any real means of finding out what is required of some child-care centres in financial terms in complying satisfactorily with the guidelines until the process has started and is working. We would support a referral to a committee six months into the program, rather than before we have adequate information as to what will happen and what is required in relation to staffing and administration costs.

In that sense, we would support that reference to the committee only if it is realistic and will have the information upon which it can make an adequate assessment and then perhaps make any necessary changes. The Greens have asked that the assessment process for the accreditation in general be made earlier than was suggested originally, and the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has agreed to that.

We have made sure, as have other groups such as the Democrats, that the process is looked at fairly soon and that—once there is time to make sure that the assessment process is realistic—the information we can obtain from assessment, both of the costs of implementing the process and of the accreditation in general, can build a better accreditation system if it needs to be improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of Senator Herron's motion to disallow the government's child-care accreditation guidelines. Once again we see intrusive government in an area in which it should not be so closely involved. I have seen it time and time again in my time in the Senate. In the area of education we are constantly battling these tiny requirements that people must fulfil. There is a whole lot of paper work to back that up and a great waste of people's time.

PARA.TAB: If this were to achieve something positive and good, we might be able to argue for it. But in this case, it is doing things that are extremely dangerous in terms of the upbringing of the next generation of Australians. I can only support wholeheartedly the remarks made in this chamber by my colleague Senator Kemp, who actually hit the nail right on the head when he spoke about what parents want for their children.

We have to understand what is happening here. We have a set of guidelines that reflect a particular philosophy. As Senator Kemp pointed out, that philosophy can be totally at variance with what the parents want. We should try to put ourselves in the position of the child, who is spending a lot of time at a preschool and a lot of time at home. What we have is a politically correct way of bringing children up in accordance with a left wing ideological position which could be—and I suggest is—at great variance with the way in which parents tend to bring up their children. That is going to sow absolute confusion in the minds of children because these guidelines actually prescribe a particular way of raising children. There is nothing magical about what has been suggested in the guidelines. There is nothing that is of actual truth in those guidelines. They reflect a philosophical position. In my former position, before I came here, I was senior lecturer in education and I was involved in the area of behaviour management. I used to lecture in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must have failed.

—No, I did not. I had a national reputation. I used to publish books on the area. I conducted seminars and I helped train teachers, both in pre-service and in service, on how to manage children in the school environment. There is a whole range of ways, and let me educate Senator Murphy on that range of ways. We can go from a completely libertarian philosophy, where we put no controls on children, right through to an authoritarian position. Many educators over the years have argued for those various positions. There is nothing magical about any of them; they reflect a particular philosophical position.

PARA.TAB: What is incredibly dangerous about these guidelines is that they reflect one philosophical position and a position which is at variance with what a great many parents want. Let me go through some of those guidelines and show the Senate how far away they are from what parents would normally do. One of the guidelines, that is stated as an unsatisfactory behaviour, is to interpret the making of a mess with food or throwing objects on the floor as naughty. Let me use that to illustrate a very basic point in the philosophical debate which has been going on in this area for many years. Dr Spock would have agreed with that and, of course, this was the way children tended to be raised in the 1950s and 1960s, particularly in the United States. After advocating for 25 years the sort of view that children should be given total freedom and no restrictions, Dr Spock actually recanted and said that he was wrong. It was a bit late to explain that to a whole generation.

What we have here is Spockism gone mad because the government is advocating this lack of restriction. Modern psychology tells us that a child feels psychologically comfortable in an environment which has boundaries, which has certain rules and restrictions. It does not have to be overly restrictive; no-one would advocate that. But there have to be a few rules and restrictions. These guidelines go totally against that.

They try to be gender neutral. The minister and I had a little altercation on this one. Let me give the minister some alternative examples to what she was saying earlier on. We have a situation where there has been a great debate in education in the area of nature and nurture. What determines human behaviour? Is it nature—in other words, our genetic disposition—that creates the behaviour, or is it nurture, the way we are brought up? What is coming out more and more strongly in the research is that it is nature, it is genetic. There are massive differences between boys and girls in that genetic make-up. We try to correct this by bringing in a set of toys and having the boys play with dolls and the girls play with trucks. How is that going to work out? Are they going to continue to do that? Is that a great thing to do?

Let me give the Senate an example from my wife's experience. She is a child-care worker. She was working with a feminist who decided that her children would be brought up in this gender neutral way. She gave her boy a doll and she gave the girl a truck. When she came back about half an hour later, the girl was making beds in the back of the truck and the boy had taken the doll apart to see how it worked.

This sort of politically correct view that is expressed in that sort of unsatisfactory guideline is a nonsense. But the more dangerous thing is the fact that all these guidelines do is reflect a particular ideological point of view and one that is not representative of the community. I cannot understand how the minister can stand there and say that the National Child Care Accreditation Council, that has made up these guidelines, is in any way representative. All that it is representative of is a few trendy left-wingers who have drawn up these guidelines that are most inappropriate. Let me go through the list of who is on the council in terms of their backgrounds—not their names, but their backgrounds. There are eight people on this council. One is a consultant; three are child-care directors; one is an academic; two are bureaucrats; there is a mandatory trade unionist; but there is no representative of any parent group. Let me emphasise that again, and perhaps the minister will listen to this instead of rabbiting on over there. There is no representative of parent groups on this council that drew up this guideline.

How a minister can be in a position to be presented with guidelines such as this, have the letters that have come in—that she has selectively quoted from—heard the debate that is going on in the community and not say to herself, `Hold it, we are on the wrong track; we need to go back and listen to people, listen to parents, and get this right' amazes me. She got up here today halfway through the debate—which absolutely amazed me; I thought she would have waited until the end when everybody had made a contribution. I thought that we were going to hear some really serious rebuttal arguments. What did we hear? We heard her reading out a series of selective quotes from some letters. Is this minister so empty-headed on this area that she cannot come up with cogent arguments to refute the case that we are making? The case that we are making is extremely strong. It is supported by great many groups of parents. It is extremely important that what parents want happens in this area.

The Jesuits have said, `Give me a child till the age of seven and then that child can go forward'. The Jesuits realise that by that stage children will go the way in which they have been trained. This is an area where children's future attitudes can be determined by what they are taught. By the age of five, children will have learnt half of what they will learn in a lifetime. It is therefore extremely important not to socially engineer what happens in these child-care centres. If parents are paying for these facilities, they must have the right to determine what happens in them and not be dictated to by a group of people who only represent their own left-wing, outdated political philosophy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the United States it is estimated that only 10 per cent of the child-care industry has availed itself of voluntary accreditation. That number is not great enough to be of any significance to parents here. Parents put their children into care—be it occasional care, long day care, or some other form of care—expecting good care. But how do parents assess whether it is good care? They cannot sit there all day and personally observe the care given.

PARA.TAB: While parents can know whether a specific child-care centre is registered according to regulation with the various state institutions, they cannot know the sort of care that is given in the centre. Parents do not know what sort of love and affection is given nor, unless they stay there all day, the sort of teaching programs implemented. The government wants to give parents some means whereby they can assess what the child-care centres have to offer—hence our proposal for accreditation.

I draw the attention of Senator Boswell to principle 17, of which he was very critical. This principle states that the program should incorporate learning experiences appropriate for each child as indicated by individual development records maintained by the staff. The developmental checklists include: the Australian development record for infants and young children; the Macquarie developmental checklist; the Denver developmental screening test; and the UK's National Children's Bureau developmental guide.

Senator Boswell omitted to list those checklists, even though they can be found in the office of every paediatrician and every infant welfare early childhood development centre. These are the rules used by those working in early childhood development to assess children's progress and development. Those rules are the means by which a professional knows whether or not children are meeting their milestones—whether their fine motor and gross motor abilities are up to scratch, whether their communication abilities are what they should be, and whether their emotional, psychological and physical development is what it should be. Those rules are the absolute basis for the delivery of good child-care: the identification of problems, the implementation of programs to assist children in their development, and the assessment of the impact of such assistance.

Two sets of carers are involved where a child spends a large part of its day away from the parents. It is important that a child-care centre can discuss with the parents whether the child's development is within the normal range. These are the essential tenets of child care and childhood development. Most parents have some idea of the range of normal behaviour and wish to be able to discuss that range, and where their child is in it, with the child-care workers. Unless the child-care workers have carefully observed the child and checked the developmental dates within these checklists, they will have no idea what the child is doing.

Another principle is good communication between the children and the parents. These are the commonsense and elementary things necessary for the provision of adequate child care. As someone who has spent a considerable part of professional life working in the early childhood area, I have no problem with these principles. I might have some problem with the wording but I have no problem with the principles that state: staff interactions with children should be warm and friendly; staff should treat all children equally and try to accommodate their individual needs; staff should respect diversity of background; and staff should treat both sexes without bias. Those are the sorts of things that parents expect their children to receive.

The health and nutrition principles state that staff should be alert to the health and welfare of each child; that staff should try to ensure that children are clothed appropriately for indoor and outdoor play and for sleep; and that staff should ensure that food and drinks meet children's daily nutritional requirements and are culturally appropriate. For example, it is commonsense that it is not appropriate to serve a Jewish child a meal that contains pork. That is the sort of thing that one would expect these centres to be sensitive to. Of course, in saying that I am not suggesting that people are not acting inappropriately at present.

I have spoken with people who work in child-care centres. They have no problem with these principles because they say that the principles cover the basic treatment and care that should be provided by anybody. Therefore, as professionals they want to aspire to these standards. These principles also give them goals.

The second part of the motion proposes that the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs inquire into and report on, by 1 February, the cost of implementation of the guidelines. A number of honourable senators have already effectively explained why the date 1 February is out of the question, and that brings me back to Senator Herron's remarks about occupational health and safety .

The Standing Committee on Community Affairs already has the heaviest workload of any senate committee. It has had to deal with a number of reports and bills and is in the middle of a major reference. We are coming up to Christmas, the time of the year when people need a break to recharge their batteries. Although I cannot speak for the opposition members on the committee—they are probably quite happy—I can speak on behalf of the government and Australian Democrats members when I say that, for reasons of our occupational health and safety, there is no way that we could physically deal with this reference. Furthermore, for reasons of the occupational health and safety of the committee secretariat there is no way that those people should be expected to be involved in such a reference at a time when they should be getting some rest. After all, we should be looking after the occupational health and safety of the committee secretariat. I therefore have much pleasure in supporting the government position on this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that these accreditation guidelines are before the parliament and that I am forced to speak on them. In so doing, I declare an interest: I have a three-year-old son who occasionally spends some time in child care—a son who actually likes playing with trucks and singing Christmas carols.

PARA.TAB: These accreditation guidelines represent authoritarian government and political correctness gone absolutely mad. The title of these guidelines should be, `How to have a politically correct child care centre, because if you do not, the government will cut you off'. I do not think honourable senators realise how absurd it is that the national parliament is discussing trucks, trains, dolls, what children will eat, et cetera, in child care centres across the country. We have a situation where a federal minister is setting herself up as the commissar of child-care, dictating what children will sing or listen to in child-care centres all over Australia. That is an utterly absurd situation which Australian people would rightly reject.

These guidelines have been quite properly condemned right across Australia. It is quite inappropriate for the federal parliament to be dealing with these guidelines. They are another example of what a former Labor minister, Peter Walsh, described as Labor allowing:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . its child-care policy to be determined by a self-serving symbiotic coalition of feminist networkers, non-market service providers and early childhood services educators.

The notion that it is only the coalition that is raising concern about this issue is negated by the fact that a former senior Labor minister for finance has been the most ardent critic of this whole scheme. The coalition has not taken the lead on this. Peter Walsh, the former Labor minister, has taken the lead on this issue. In an article in the Australian Financial Review on 21 September under the heading, `Childcare Mafia do it again', in referring to the accreditation scheme, Peter Walsh made a point which has not been dealt with by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). He said:
My inquiries reveal that not only is there no Cabinet authority for that policy, Cabinet rejected it this year as it has done on at least two previous occasions. But it keeps cropping up again.
It appears that the ideologues who run that dreadful childcare division in the Department of Community Services have decided again to ignore any Cabinet decision with which they disagree.

If there is any residual commonsense in government, it should be used to close down the public sector service-provider-inspired National Accreditation Council, saving the $11m it proposes to squander over the next four years.

Those are the words of a former Labor minister for finance. I could not agree more and nor could any honourable senators on this side of the house. But, of course, the criticism does not come only from within the Labor ranks. People in the child-care industry have risen up against this whole proposal.

PARA.TAB: The most compelling letter I received—if we are into letters, let us have a look at some—was from the Sydney Rescue Work Society, an organisation which cares for 1,500 children per day in Sydney. That organisation has asked us to vote against the guidelines, and I will vote against the guidelines just on the basis of what it has said. It summed it up in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has not provided satisfactory evidence that this proposal will not increase costs and cause hardship to the lower paid, most vulnerable and disadvantaged parents.
This government which professes to stand for the workers of Australia is in fact through this scheme going to hit them the hardest. The letter further said:
Government schemes that affect the community and have resource implications must ensure affordability, equity and accessibility. The proposals do not satisfy these criteria.

This very good letter then set out all the reasons why these proposals should be rejected. This scheme has also been attacked by the Australian Confederation of Childcare. Mrs Ann Young, the President of that organisation said recently:

What we are against is the Government's provocative insistence on bludgeoning centres into being a part of the scheme by threatening to withdraw fee relief from low-income families who send their children to a centre which is not part of the scheme.
How do you answer that? As a South Australian, I feel compelled to quote the President of the Association of Child Care Centres of South Australia, Mr Hayden Trewethick. He made the very good point:

. . . the guidelines would impact heavily on centres of Greek Orthodox, Catholic or Anglican influence where children were sent for specific cultural or religion aspects. "That takes away the parents' choice," Mr Tremethick said.

PARA.TAB: "They are trying to make all child care centres the same. There's a social engineering aspect to it which is worrying.
"Certain people within government have got a model of what they think a child care centre should be and they are trying to make all child care centres conform to that model.
"They are taking from parents and families the freedom and right to choose the care they think is most appropriate for their child.
"I see it as the thin edge of the wedge,".

SPEECH.PARA: That was from the president of a child-care operation in South Australia. He makes that very good point about the imposition of uniformity. People can have their values in the child-care centre of their choice if they want but as a parent I reject the values which this government is seeking to impose on child-care centres all over Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is one matter that has not been referred to in this debate which was touched on by Senator Boswell some time ago, and that is the enforcement of these guidelines. How are they going to be enforced? If we look at the guidelines themselves—what we have been referring to in these 52 principles is simply a schedule to the guidelines—clause 18 actually talks about enforcement. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Does the operator of the centre allow inspections?

PARA.TAB: 18.(1) The operator of an eligible child care centre must, at any time during the centre's hours of operation:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) allow an authorised officer to enter the centre to ensure that the centre is being operated in accordance with these guidelines; and
(b) provide the authorised officer with all reasonable facilities and assistance to allow the officer to act under paragraph (a).

PARA.TAB: (2) The operator of a centre must, at any time during the centre's hours of operation:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) make the records referred to in clauses—
which are quite detailed—
. . . available for inspection, and copying, by an authorised officer; and
(b) allow an authorised officer to enter the centre to inspect and copy the records; and
(c) provide the authorised officer with all reasonable facilities and assistance to allow the officer to inspect and copy the records.

What is an authorised officer? The interpretation clause at the start of the guidelines provides that `authorised' means authorised by the minister for the purposes of these guidelines. This is a ministerial directive. Again we come back to the commissar of child-care centres. These are politically correct guidelines that are going to be enforced by the minister's PC police, who can enter any centre at any time for any reason to ensure, presumably, that people are not playing Christmas carols too often.

PARA.TAB: What staggers me is that we have had this minister stand up and say that next year is going to be the year of the family and that what we want to highlight is diversity in families. But when we come to child-care centres we have a crushing uniformity that is an imposition of the values of this particular government.

In my humble view, the minimum standards, which we do support for child-care centres, are not a matter for the federal government. They are quite properly a matter for state governments and should not even be debated in this parliament. It is absurd that they are being debated in this parliament.

What is next? If this is taken to its logical extreme, we are about to have parent accreditation. Parents, if they are to get fee relief, will have to pass some sort of test as to whether they have the correct values to bring up children according to the values of this particular government.

The minister has denied there will be a problem, but I think down the track we must fear that the child-care rebate scheme will be linked to this accreditation scheme and that parents will get a child-care rebate only if they send their children to an accredited child-care centre. That will be the next step to ensure that all child-care centres across Australia conform to the uniformity of this government. It is a scheme which is a disgrace and should be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to enter this debate. I must say that since this issue has blown up, particularly in the last two weeks, the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, has stood a very lonely figure in defending the government's position—more so this morning and this afternoon when this debate was brought to the house. Senator Crowley must feel a very lonely minister on that front bench because, quite frankly, we have not seen one frontbench minister come through here to defend her—
—Hey!

—other than Senator Faulkner. He claims that as a defence. He enters the house to extend the debating time. If Senator Faulkner is genuine he will stay around. I challenge him to stay around and defend Senator Crowley because what I am saying is that no-one from the front bench has stayed to defend her. The longest stay we have had has been from Senator Chris Evans, a newcomer to the Senate—a backbencher. He stayed longer than anyone.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator McGauran, I think you actually mean Senator Murphy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murphy?

SPEECH.PARA: An opposition senator—They are all the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague says, they are all the same. He is so new, I do not know his name, but I wish him well in his career. But he will not do his career justice if he comes in here to back Senator Crowley because quite frankly he should be looking to take her position, which will be up for grabs very soon.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that the government does not support Senator Crowley on this matter. She has rushed ahead of her supply lines. We know this for a fact because there are great rumblings in the corridor about Senator Crowley's handling of this matter and more so about the accreditation handbook and the linking to it of funding.

As far back as last year, the very powerful Labor Party caucus subcommittee on child care stated that there is a widespread feeling that, with regard to the child-care system in Australia, now we have got it right and there is no need to change it. Senator Crowley does not even have the support of the caucus subcommittee. I notice that she is leaving the chamber. Now there is no-one on the government side, except Senator Foreman, to defend the government. Perhaps Senator Crowley has thrown in the towel. I suspect she has not thrown in the towel.

The point is that nobody in the government is really supporting Senator Crowley on this matter. I say to Senator Lees from the Australian Democrats: so be it if we lose the debate today. That seems to be the way in which it is heading. But we have won the career of Senator Crowley. Quite frankly, having regard to her defence today, no government in its right mind would keep a person like her on the front bench. The government will give her a bit of time; it will let a few months lapse. But it cannot keep Senator Crowley on the front bench because she cannot defend her position. Moreover, she has now caused a great lack of confidence in the industry. She has split it asunder. Senator Faulkner, welcome back to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran, would you like to address your remarks through the chair?

—Yes, I will. I make the point that, whatever has been achieved out of this, without doubt, Senator Crowley's career has been severely damaged by this. I take some degree of pleasure in that, as does everyone on this side of the house. Quite frankly, it is rather chilling that this minister is overseeing the Year of the Family in 1994. We on this side of the house would prefer to see someone else take it up, someone like Senator Reynolds—someone in whom the community has some confidence. Senator Faulkner, if he sticks around long enough, could take up that challenge in 1994. It is a chilling prospect to know that Senator Crowley will be overseeing the Year of the Family in 1994.

PARA.TAB: I want to make the point again, Madam Acting Deputy President, now that you are in the chair, that I will be referring a matter to the President for his consideration. I know what I have seen, and Senator Boswell knows what has occurred in this chamber. I refer to Senator Crowley's adviser. I think the matter should be taken up by the President. I signal the fact that I will be referring the matter to the President for his consideration. If nothing else, I would like a ruling on such matters that can be sent to the advisers and the public servants and that they be severely cautioned about it because next time, if not this time, it will be a matter of misconduct.

It is true to say that Senator Crowley's handbook was conceived by a very small clique, governed by the minister, which does not have the support of the industry today. In fact, I noticed in a newspaper today that in the last 24 hours she has cobbled together a small team of supporters. It is a bit too late, I would say, because the extent to which the industry does not support Senator Crowley's handbook has been on the front page of every newspaper in this country. But she has managed to cobble together a group called the Coalition for Good Child Care. That group has been put together in the last couple of days to try to turn around the perception, to turn around the media debate. They are not representative of the industry. The group is made up of an ABC reporter and academics from TAFE colleges. Quite simply, it is not representative of the community.

As my colleagues have said, this is the worst case of social engineering to come out of the government. The government really has gone over the top this time. All the evidence shows that Senator Crowley's department is seeking to snatch the minds of children away from their parents—from those parents who dare to instil in their children views which are different from those of this government. As Senator Kemp said, the succinct point to be made is that it is the government control that everyone is seriously objecting to. Quite frankly, there is more than one way to abuse children, and Senator Crowley's department has found the other way.

What is worse, as I said before, is that this minister is overseeing the Year of the Family in 1994, yet she in no way understands or is in any form connected with mainstream thinking and values in Australia. She should know that those mainstream Australian family values are rock solid against this handbook, and they will not be moved from that position. This handbook does no more than prove that a gulf has opened up between the Canberra thinking and mainstream Australia. If ever Canberra has been isolated, this is the best example yet.

When I am talking about a mainstream family, that family could be a married couple with two children, a married couple with four children, a single parent with a child, or a divorced couple with a child. Those examples all make up the definition of a family, but in regard to each one of those four examples none of those parents would accept the values embodied in this handbook. No parent, as we know, accepts any of the rules or principles embodied in this handbook so long as they are handed down from on high by the government. I am talking about the four basic examples of what can make up a family.

It is a very sad day in this country when children cannot listen to Silent Night without a government dictum on the matter. It is a very sterile play yard in which boys cannot play with tip-trucks. Yet that will be the effect of Senator Crowley's child-care laws. We know that for a fact because of the English experience, where there is a very similar type of handbook. The handbook in England is in a far more advanced state. The London Preschool Playgroups Association spokesman has admitted that Christmas has been abandoned in many of the child-care centres in inner London. Quite remarkably, he used a very similar defence to that of Senator Crowley. He said, `It is up to the individual groups to interpret these guidelines'.

So long as a child-care centre's funding depends on those guidelines, it will err on the side of caution and interpret them in the way in which Canberra and the public servants want it to; otherwise, funding will be at risk. It is as simple as that. The example exists in England. Quite frankly, examples already exist in my state of Victoria—in a Coburg child-care centre where Christmas has been abandoned. When a centre's funding depends on obeying government laws, of course it is not going to risk the employment of many of the teachers or, indeed, the viability of the centre itself.

Senator Crowley says, `If Christmas is not being celebrated in any of the child-care centres, call me; get me on the phone'. Yet Senator Crowley has made no attempt to withdraw the mention of Christmas from the handbook. If she had a point to make in the handbook, could she not have made it without the best case example being that of Christmas? She obviously has no idea of the sensitivity of the issue. If she has a point to make, she should pull Christmas out and make the point in another way. That would be far more acceptable. But she has given no commitment to take out the word `Christmas'. She is still going to approve this handbook lock, stock and barrel, with the word `Christmas' contained in it. She will allow the interpretation to be such—as it has already been in many child-care centres; the best example being in England—that Christmas will be banned so long as she hangs the threat of funding over those child-care centres.

I refer to the handbook to give credence to the argument regarding Christmas. Senator Lees conveniently left it out. It did not matter how many times we attempted to interject and point it out to her; she was quite determined to leave out the crux of this debate—that is, the unsatisfactory column in principle 21. A centre which comes under this column heading will find its funding in danger. According to page 53, it is `Unsatisfactory' if:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a constant repetition of Christmas songs as background at the end of the year.

Of course, Christmas is celebrated only at the end of the year. It is an exclusive celebration in this country as it has always been throughout the world. It is accepted in all countries yet, incredibly, this is placed in the unsatisfactory column. Any teacher or parent could draw only one conclusion.

PARA.TAB: In the basic column, which is the next category up and one category down from unsatisfactory—which is basically unsatisfactory in itself, and again Senator Lees did not put this in perspective—Christmas is mentioned as being `culturally irrelevant for many children'. So Senator Crowley cannot tell us she is not trying to shape Christmas in the way that she, or her department, wants it. If Senator Crowley wants to make a point or an example, she should pull the references to Christmas out of this handbook and treat it in another way; but she cannot tell us that she is not trying to reshape and socially engineer Christmas.

Senator Crowley might care to know that many non-Christian children enjoy singing Christmas carols with their friends. Asian nations that are not predominantly Christian understand and indeed celebrate Christmas—perhaps not in the true religious sense; but they recognise it as a world, particularly a Western world, celebration. Not even in the darkest days of communism was Christmas eradicated. If Senator Crowley truly wishes to eradicate the concern about Christmas, I again challenge her to take the word `Christmas' out of the handbook.

Senator Crowley also used the argument that the handbook is no more than a set of guidelines for child-care centres. That argument is false. It is a desperate attempt to slip-slide away from the original aim of enforcement of the guidelines. Firstly, the principles to be followed are placed in four categories: unsatisfactory, basic, good quality and high quality. The allocation of funds will depend upon an assessment of the categories into which centres are placed. Every child-care centre realises that the money trail leads back to the minister's desk. Such centres will not risk their funding, nor the employment of their teachers, and so will attempt to place themselves in the highest category. While Christmas is placed in the unsatisfactory category, child-care centres will err on the side of caution and will choose to abolish Christmas so as not to risk an unsatisfactory assessment.

Secondly, the fact that the accreditation principles are linked to funding was confirmed by the National Child Care Accreditation Council Chairperson and Chief Executive, Quentin Bryce. She was in conflict with the minister when she said that in order to gain accreditation a centre would have to achieve a good quality rating in at least 32 to 52 of the principles. She is basically saying that a centre would have to get all 52 right if it really wanted its funding. At the very least, it would have to get between 32 and 52 principles right. A centre cannot receive an unsatisfactory rating in any of the principles if it is going to meet Quentin Bryce's classification. If a centre is going to get between 32 and 52 principles right, it cannot get one unsatisfactory category at all.

Thirdly, the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres tabled with the handbook clearly states that there is a linkage between funding and the handbook. Given the time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the last page of the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres which was tabled in the Senate on 7 October.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before, since this matter has come under public scrutiny, the minister has really found herself to be alone—except for a small clique of social engineers—in her support of this handbook. Senator Crowley has espoused the view that the accreditation principles have been formulated by the industry—how many times have we heard that from Senator Crowley—after broad consultation. The opposite is true and I make these points in support of my case.

PARA.TAB: The National Child Care Accreditation Council—which is held up as a body at arms-length from government and which it is claimed sought industry views in compiling the handbook principles—has exposed itself as being very much in with this Labor government in its drive to manipulate the social agenda. Quite frankly, it is no more than a government lackey. I notice that the minister quoted from the Telegraph Mirror. To show just what a government lackey the accreditation council is, I refer to the fact that two of its members resigned in disgust and disappointment because there had not been broad consultation with the industry about this handbook. That is enough to give that council away; we have the inside word on it.

Talking about the inside word, we also have the inside word on the government and support for Senator Crowley. It comes from former Senator Walsh. Former Senator Walsh really gives Senator Crowley away in a manner in which only he can—as those who knew former Senator Walsh would know. I will quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review of 30 November 1993. In that article, former Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley claimed last week the "industry had asked for the system". Last year I asked the previous minister how many requests for compulsory accreditation had been received from parent/users or managers of private sector centres which provide more than half the services. Answer: No records have been kept—
Former Senator Walsh adds—
which translated means very few or none.

So the industry was really not consulted at all. Senator Crowley has felt the heat of public opinion on this matter. In desperation last weekend at a Canberra conference she even lashed out at Australian women. I do not know why she thought Australian women would come to her defence but, quite incredibly, she lashed out at them. This was reported in the Canberra Times. She said that Australian women were vicious and were unpleasant, and she said how disappointed she was that Australian women did not support her in this matter. This is a good example of Senator Crowley believing everyone thinks like her. She seems to believe all Australian women think like her, but the truth is quite the opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator McGauran is deliberately misquoting; he does not have the newspaper there. I did not refer to Australian women; I referred precisely to the women who came to this Parliament House and harassed my staff. That is actually in evidence from officials of Parliament House who made it clear that they had to support my staff. I draw Senator McGauran's attention to the fact that he should be accurate in this matter.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so, Madam Acting Deputy President, but we will not get bogged down on that point. All I can say is that there is a deafening silence from Australian women in support of Senator Crowley on this matter—except of course some such as Quentin Bryce and a very small clique coming out of Canberra.

PARA.TAB: With just a short time to go, I would like to match Senator Crowley's points in regard to newspaper articles and public opinion. But, first of all, I think the challenge before Senator Crowley—and she made a most disappointing defence of the handbook—is to culturally explain the meanings and aims of the book. That is what we are really after: a cultural explanation of the meanings and aims of the handbook. What is the cultural meaning and aim of believing that it is unsatisfactory to say, `That's a pretty dress you have on' or `That's nice' or `No' or `Naughty', or that it is unsatisfactory for boys to play only with tip-trucks and girls to play only with dolls—or, worse, the abolition of Christmas carols, that being the effect? Senator Crowley has to explain what she means by that culturally, but she will not go into it.

I challenge Senator Crowley to explain to the Senate the meaning behind the handbook. The grave danger is that, with what she is doing, she is presenting moral confusion between the values of the home and the government and government funded child-care centres. As Senator Kemp has pointed out, the answer really is that this should be driven by parental expectations.

First of all, I refer to children's views of Christmas. On 25 November, the Herald-Sun newspaper took a survey of some children. I will just read out the view of Christmas of four of the children. The question was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you like singing Christmas carols?
Rebecca, four years old, answered:
I like Christmas because every day you sing those songs and I love singing.
Victoria, five years old, answered:
It's fun singing Christmas songs because you can dance at the same time and we have a special concert.
Aleksandar, three years old, said:
I like Christmas songs.
Felicity, four years old, said:
Christmas songs are good fun.

I think what really sums up the children's point of view, if they themselves could speak out and articulate their feelings on this handbook, is the picture, which I think tells a thousand words, that the Herald-Sun newspaper caught and printed on its front page on 25 November. To that end, I also seek to incorporate this picture in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran, pictures cannot be incorporated. It is not technologically possible, I am advised.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, if I could just help you there, it has been done once before for Senator Ian Campbell.
—That was a graph, I understand.

—Then I seek leave that an attempt be made to check the technology and just see if it is indeed possible. It is a most important picture—and I should describe it for Hansard's sake. It shows a young girl holding her doll, with the caption:

SPEECH.PARA: LOVE HUG: Little Tegan's doll could mean childcare centre trouble.
A new childcare rule-book . . . and it's goodbye dolly
I really believe that picture tells the story from the children's point of view. I do seek leave to incorporate it and for the technology to be reviewed to see if it can be incorporated.
