—Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator McGauran's words were that `an attempt be made'. He says, `Okay, I am not able to do this', after being advised, and then he says, `Could an attempt be made?'. I do not want to split hairs, but we could spend some time describing what is meant by `an attempt be made'. If Senator McGauran means by that that Hansard inquires or reports back whether it is feasible or not, I think that is acceptable. But is that what Senator McGauran's definition of an attempt is?
—Yes, if Hansard could report back.
—If Senator McGauran is prepared to accept that definition of `attempt' so that we do not have people making definitions and chasing Hansard up and down the country, I would give leave.
—Leave is granted.
—I surely hope that we do reach a stage where Hansard does have that technology because there will be many pictures that speak a thousand words.
—The thought of that is too terrible, Senator McGauran.
—Having heard from the children, here are some of the parents' points of view—and I will keep this short and sharp. From the Herald-Sun on 6 December, Mrs Dawn Fischer writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Surely this move calls for mass rebellion.
Surely it does and surely that is what has happened. Bev Warburton says to Senator Crowley:
So butt out of family life.
That is very succinct. Kathy Djoneff says:
Linking childcare payments to a set of conditions under which children are to be raised is the most insidious form of blackmail.

We have heard from the parents, we have heard from the children and we have heard from the associations that predominantly represent the child-care centres, such as the Australian Confederation of Child Care and the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations. We heard from other groups which represent the poorest of families—the Sydney Rescue Works Society and the Catholic Social Services, which describe the handbook linking to funding as `despicable'. We have heard from the two members who have resigned from the accreditation council. We have heard from petitioners and we have had phone calls. All honourable senators, from both sides of the chamber, if they are honest, would say that their offices have been swamped with calls regarding this matter. We have also received letters in our electorate offices.

PARA.TAB: What does Senator Crowley do? She has the numbers on the floor. That may be the case today but this has a long way to go. She still has to get the cooperation of those child-care centres for them to sign an agreement in relation to this handbook accreditation. I can tell her that they will rebel against that. They have lost confidence in the minister. They will not accept this handbook. They will call something similar to a coalminers strike—which would be very tragic in this country—in that the child care workers will refuse government funding, but that is the situation that they are fast being pushed into. I would like to know whether the minister will withhold their funding if they do not sign the agreement in relation to this accreditation handbook. The minister is not listening. She has not listened for the last three or four weeks. I do not think we will get much satisfaction until she is removed from her position and someone with more competence is put in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because much of the ground that needs to be covered has been covered. I would like to make a couple of extra comments. I have in front of me a document, the first sentence of which says, `When I die they can write what they like on my tombstone as long as it's not "she meant well"'. I am not as unkind as some of my colleagues on this side because I believe that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), with all her intentions, means very well in this situation with regard to child-care guidelines. I am quite sure that Senator Lees means well when she speaks in defence of these guidelines, and Senator Chamarette when she talks about quality child care. But it is not a matter of just meaning well; it is a matter of the political philosophy that lies behind one's support or otherwise of these particular guidelines and the effect that they will have on a young generation of Australians.

PARA.TAB: I speak as a parent of three children. I have to declare that none of my three children ever spent time in a child-care centre. There were two major reasons for that. Firstly, 100 miles from the metropolitan area there was no child-care centre for those children to attend. A second and even more important reason was that, when my wife and I decided that we would like to bring children into this world, we believed that the best child care that those children could possibly have was being reared in a home by two parents who loved them and who wanted to make sure that the best that they could get out of life was provided for them. One may say that that is all very well if one can afford it, because current economic circumstances would suggest that there are a number of parents who can no longer afford to keep their children at home with one of the parents—either the father or the mother—spending the time at home to rear those children.

In the late 1960s farming was not a very lucrative enterprise. We could scarcely afford to raise our children to the extent that we wanted to. But the overriding factor was that we believed that if we chose to bring children into this world we should do everything possible to make sure that we accepted the responsibility of rearing those children. If we get to the situation where parents put their children into child care either by choice or because of economic necessity, which is sometimes quoted as the case now, I agree with Senator Chamarette when she says that we must be sure that we have quality child care for those children. Senator Chamarette used the word `quality' quite often during her speech.

My three children, none of whom spent any time in child-care centres, are either working in or have worked in child-care centres over the past seven years. Although they did not benefit from spending any time in a child-care centre, they have all worked in child-care centres. We speak regularly and they tell me what they think is appropriate child care for children who are required to attend child-care centres.

I agree with a lot of the things in the guidelines because they happen at the moment. They are only a statement of what actually happens in child-care centres right now. However, there are many things in the guidelines that I could not possibly agree with. The guidelines try to get uniformity in what we expect should be available to all children. To think that we should tie fee relief to accreditation for those child-care centres that follow the guidelines that the government has sought to get approval for is the worst way of making sure that we have what we want by way of care for our children in child-care centres.

I have been led to believe that the quality of child care in Australia is currently considered to be amongst the best in the world. That is without these accreditation guidelines. I cannot understand why it is necessary in the first place for these guidelines to be put into writing so that the bureaucracy can check up and make sure that they are being adhered to by every child-care centre in Australia.

Why should the child-care centres not provide the kind of environment that parents want for their children? The parents who place their children in child care have many different wishes for the care of those children. As our children get older we are allowed to choose to send them to a Christian school if we wish. We are also allowed to send them to a Muslim school or a Jewish school if that is what we wish to do. Parents are allowed to choose where they send their children in their later stages of education, so why on earth are we looking at this sort of uniformity in child care?

As a parent, I may choose to put my young children into a child-care centre which insists on a stronger form of discipline. This may be different from what `modern' parents may choose for their children. I would not like the idea of my child being allowed to throw food on the floor as a form of exploratory behaviour. I would not choose that, so why should I not be able to put my child into a child-care centre where discipline is considered to be important?

As Senator Kemp so ably said—and he was supported by Senator Tierney—why should not there be a diversity rather than uniformity in our nation which encourages multiculturalism and encourages all the other things that are different? Why are we looking at uniformity when in lots of other areas we are encouraging diversity? I believe that it should be the parents' choice. If they choose to put their child into a child-care centre, then they should be able to choose the type of child-care centre that they want and they should still be eligible for fee relief without that child-care centre necessarily passing all of the guidelines that are in this document of uniformity which this government is now trying to force on child-care centres throughout the nation.

As I said, I agree with lots of the things in the guidelines because I think they are put in practice right now. I agree with most of those things which we would consider to be the norm in a majority of child-care centres, but which, according to the guidelines, are considered necessary to be put down in writing. Some of the extreme measures have been mentioned by my colleagues. I am sure that when some are put in practice, they will not be quite as difficult as they perhaps appear to be on paper. But I am quite sure that there are enough extreme measures to disturb the parents and the families of young children who wish to avail themselves of the use of the child-care centres.

I think we are going beyond the pale when we start talking about authorised officers going into child-care centres to make sure that the guidelines are being adhered to. I think it is going too far to have authorised officers who can go into a child-care centre and make sure that all of those things that this government thinks are good for rearing children, including behavioural situations, in child-care centres are being adhered to. I hate to think that we would ever get to the day when we have a commissar for child care. It seems as though these guidelines are heading in that direction and it is typical of the sort of bureaucratic involvement that this government would like to have in relation to the standards of child care in Australia.

I do not intend to speak any longer because most of the issues have been covered, but I wish to stress strongly the idea of parents' choice. Parents should be able to send their children to child-care centres which give them the sort of care and control that they would wish to give them in their own homes. If that choice cannot be left to the parents, then I think that these guidelines for accreditation should be strongly opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for this debate is rapidly coming to a close. I wish to make a very short contribution under those circumstances. I do so because I claim to know a little bit about children and the needs of children. I have never been consulted about these sorts of things and, more importantly, my wife has never been consulted about them. I should think she knows a great deal about the care and nurturing of children.

PARA.TAB: I note the comments of Senator Ferguson. I have a couple of grown-up daughters who are working in the child-care industry. I also have grandchildren who attend child-care centres. I have taken the opportunity of discussing these guidelines and the quality improvement and accreditation system handbook principles with a number of people, including those whom I have mentioned, but the guidelines do not attract any support at all.

I am not criticising or questioning for one moment the genuineness or goodwill of the people who have drafted these principles. I am not questioning the integrity of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). I simply think the guidelines are foolish and, worse than that, I think they will impact adversely on the poor; they will prejudice the poor. Bureaucratic costs will necessarily be passed on to the child-care centres. These will be passed on to the poor benighted parents, many of whom are struggling because of the policies of this government. Many families are now unable to make ends meet on one income. Therefore, they do not have a true freedom of choice to do what Senator Ferguson was saying many desire to do, which is to have one of the parents in the home, nurturing and caring for the children full time.

Survey after survey has shown that many persons are forced out into the paid work force when their desire is to predominantly involve themselves in the full-time care and nurturing of their children in their own homes. This has been denied to them by the actions of this government and successive governments. Of course, this is not the time to argue that case. These regulations are just another example of the costs being passed on to those families who need the services of child-care centres. That factor needs to be considered.

The other factor that has been canvassed by quite a number of honourable senators is the need to distinguish between the desire to have top quality child-care institutions and the introduction of compulsory patterns of child care, tying them to the child-care rebate. Once we go along the latter track, we open the way for the bureaucratic control of the children of this country and we take away the rights of parents. That approach has been met by an absolute barrage of condemnation. That is why these principles that are contained in the document that is before us have met with such opposition. The very suggestion that the state will involve itself in the control of the children of Australian parents has met with a justifiably angry reaction by those parents.

I congratulate the opposition, including Senator Herron, on moving this motion. I believe it is time that the government took a step back and reconsidered what it is doing in this area, reconsidered the principles that are contained in this document and reconsidered the tying of accreditation of child-care centres with the payment of rebates to parents. The government should distinguish between those things, but it has not. It has chosen to do it in a different way.

I know there are quite a number of members of the government who do not agree with the tying of accreditation to the payment of the child-care rebate. I hope that those people raise very strongly with the minister their objections and voice the objections of the many hundreds of thousands of parents throughout Australia who will be very upset about this. I support the motion that has been moved by Senator Herron.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank my colleagues and Senator Harradine for their support of this motion. I think all of us on both sides of this chamber would agree that there has been enormous community interest in the matters that lie before us. Those matters are indicative of the strength of community feeling which has been expressed not only in newspapers but also on television and on radio.

PARA.TAB: We have seen an orchestration of support even in today's newspapers by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). She realises her own vulnerability on this issue. We have seen that, in fact, in the continuation of this debate through the normal period of adjournment for our lunch-hour. There are so many members who wish to speak in this debate that we have had to curtail the time in which they can speak. As you well know, Madam Acting Deputy President, that does not happen very often; it is a rare occurrence in this chamber. It is a reflection of the depth of feeling in the community over the guidelines.

I would address some remarks to the Democrats. I have before me a letter that was sent to Senator Spindler by Mr Roger Nicholls, Minister for Community Development; the Family in Western Australia. It did not come out in the debate. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator

A recent news item here in Western Australia described how the Australian Democrats would take their push for a bill of rights to the community next year. It spoke of community meetings beginning in February and leading to a draft bill of rights by August.

I ask you, as a matter of urgency, to consider how you could draft a bill of rights which actually respected parents' rights and simultaneously permitted the Commonwealth to introduce its proposed National Childcare Accreditation Scheme.
It would border on farce to sign away fundamental rights and then go to the community to discuss a bill of rights.

Despite all the platitudes that have been, and will be, expressed about noble motives and the `good' things in the accreditation scheme, the fact is that the Commonwealth is trying to impose a number of beliefs and attitudes which many people might find unwise or objectionable. Some who may find the beliefs and attitudes admirable would be alarmed that the Commonwealth is imposing them by threatening to deprive parents of their childcare payments if they choose a child care centre which does not enforce these beliefs and attitudes.

Senator Lees of the Democrats—and I respect her emotional involvement in this, because she has had experience in the field—did not address the link of fee relief to accreditation, which is a very fundamental aspect of the whole debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Economic blackmail.

—Exactly, Senator Harradine. I want to address the Greens because they have a significant part to play in the determination of the vote that will occur. At this very late hour, I make a plea for them to consider their position. They have asked for and got the minister's agreement for a review in six month's time. Surely they realise that the horse will have bolted in six months time. Again, it will be the minister judging the minister's actions: Caesar judging Caesar. How can we expect an independent review under those circumstances?

PARA.TAB: I have moved that this legislation be sent to the Community Affairs Committee so that it can look at the disparity between the cost per week per child of 88c arrived at by the minister and the cost of $30 arrived at by the independent consultant's review. The minister said that it had nothing to do with the extra hours needed by child-care centres.
When one looks at what is required for instance—this is in the guidelines—one sees that the program includes excursions to exhibitions and performances. The guidelines state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . children are brought into contact with the creativity of others through visits from musicians, artists, dancers, puppeteers and drama groups.
I would like to know how we are going to get that for 88c per child per week. Another item reads:
The centre maintains a full immunisation record which is updated as appropriate.

These are but some examples of what I am referring to in terms of costs. Many others along the same lines appear in the guidelines. I make a plea to the Greens to reconsider their position as we have not yet had the vote and will be having it after question time this afternoon. There is still time for them to determine their position.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I refer to the minister. The minister had no defence of the link between fee relief and accreditation. She spent at least five minutes of her time attacking me over something I was supposed to have said when the Hansard will reveal that I was quoting former Senator Peter Walsh, who believed that there may be a hidden agenda. I was quoting from his speech of the time.

There has been no substantive response whatsoever to the arguments put forward by the opposition, and indeed Senator Harradine, to the motion. There has been no substantive response to the complaints about the guidelines themselves or about the social engineering that is apparent to anybody who takes the trouble to read the guidelines.

More particularly about the minister, I am sad about her response and I am sorry for her because, while she has apparently listened, she has not heard what has come from the community. There are none so blind as those who do not wish to see, and she has taken no notice. A course has been set for her. I was screamed at by her adviser in the box because I implied that she did not know what was going on. I have reconsidered my position. It is not the place for advisers to engage in debate in this chamber.

Over all of that, I am sad for the minister because when one looks at those guidelines—I invite everybody who is listening to us today and interested in this field to apply to the minister's office for a set of the guidelines—one sees that there is one thing that does not appear in those guidelines, one extremely important thing; that is, commonsense. There is none whatsoever. There is no commonsense in those guidelines.

I am speaking to two matters in this debate. One is the disallowance of the guidelines—there will be a separate vote on each of these matters—and the second is the referral to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Those votes will be taken after question time today and I believe there is still time for the Greens to reconsider their position in that regard. As I understand, the opposition has Senator Harradine's support on these matters. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I ask: is the minister aware of reports this morning that the foreign minister of Thailand has offered to act as mediator in the current dispute between Australia and Malaysia? As both Senator Evans and the Prime Minister seem to be completely incapable of resolving this dispute, has the government ruled out seeking outside help?

—Any assistance from Foreign Minister Prasong, or from any of the ASEAN countries, that might be offered and might be appropriate would be very welcome and very warmly received. At this stage we are not seeking any formal mediation. We do think it is an issue that should be resolved between the two countries and is capable of resolution between us.

PARA.TAB: This morning I had a long conversation with my Malaysian counterpart, Abdullah Badawi. It was a helpful conversation. The dialogue between us is continuing. Beyond that, I have absolutely nothing to say about the content of it. The Minister for Defence, Robert Ray, also had a cordial meeting in Langkawi this morning with his defence counterpart.None of us underestimate the degree of difficulty that will be involved in getting the relationship back on the rails, but we are trying very hard to do just that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What help does the minister think ASEAN foreign ministers might be able to offer? For example, could they give our Prime Minister some education on the sensitivities of the region?
—Whatever help we receive, it is likely to be far more considerable, far more objective and far more positive than the help we are getting from the opposition parties in this country at the moment.

—I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Following the announcement of the establishment of a national transport planning task force in October and the subsequent support expressed within the industry for this initiative, I understand that a detailed discussion paper has been released. Can the minister advise the Senate what the goals of the task force will be with the release of this paper?

—This first attempt to bring together all of the transport systems in Australia into a cohesive whole is extremely important, particularly for states like Queensland, in improving both freight and passenger flows around Australia. As all honourable senators would be aware, Australia's transport system is undergoing a process of fundamental reform.

PARA.TAB: Deregulation of domestic aviation has produced significant positive results for Australia. The waterfront and shipping reform programs and the establishment of both the National Rail Corporation and the National Road Transport Commission are changing the face of transport in Australia. These changes, which followed decades of neglect by conservative governments in Australia, will now allow us to focus on the transport system as a whole for the first time.

The government is determined to improve the efficiency within and between each link of the transport chain. This task force has been established under high-level industry leadership to help us to do that. It has been asked to examine the adequacy of transport infrastructure and operational systems to meet the nation's future transport needs.

The task force has had several substantive meetings and it now intends to consult widely with a broad range of parties including, of course, territory governments, state governments and, primarily, the industry itself. The discussion paper released today will be sent to over 150 of these organisations and it represents the first step in this consultative process.

In establishing the task force, the government was very conscious of ensuring that it was industry and user oriented and this is reflected in the paper. I particularly want to endorse statements appearing in this morning's media from the chairman of the task force, Ian Webber, about his concern that the task force should be seen to focus on those areas where the nation could achieve the greatest benefits in terms of human capital and capital investment.

I am also heartened by the desire of the task force to ensure that, at the end of the day, it gives the government practical and implementable recommendations. I encourage participation by all interested parties in the work of the task force and commend the discussion paper to honourable senators as a vital step in creating, for the first time, a truly integrated national transport system in Australia. I table the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I wonder whether at this stage in tabling the paper the minister is able to comment on the movement of interstate freight, particularly in relation to freight costs in remote areas?

—The terms of reference of the committee require it to give primary regard to issues relating to the interstate movement of freight, reflecting the national focus of the task force's role. However, interrelationships exist between interstate and intrastate freight. The point has been properly made that an enormous amount of freight—in fact, the majority of it—is intrastate rather than interstate. It will be essential for the task force to examine a wide range of issues that may not necessarily be contained within its terms of reference—particularly the links between intrastate and interstate freight—in its examination of these issues.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. Is it the fact that the 2 December press release by a spokesman for the Prime Minister—rather than the Prime Minister, which is a deliberate snub in itself—claiming that the Malaysian government has made no official protest to Australia was released after the Deputy Secretary-General of the Malaysian foreign affairs ministry had verbally expressed Malaysian displeasure in the strongest terms to the Australian High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur? In these circumstances, why does the Prime Minister continue to add insult to injury by denying the fact that Malaysia has indeed made a formal protest and continues to very strongly resent the Prime Minister's behaviour?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I ask for all of those interjections to be incorporated in Hansard, Mr President! I am afraid that, essentially, this boils down to a semantic question, as so many of these things do. There was a clear assurance, for example, by the Malaysian High Commissioner as late as 4 December that Malaysia's earlier comments did not constitute a formal diplomatic protest. That was certainly our understanding of the nature of the communications at the time that they were made.

PARA.TAB: However, it is the case that Dr Mahathir on 3 December characterised these earlier expressions and Malaysian views as having been a protest, and I guess we are obliged to accept his characterisation of it. It is the case that views can be expressed through diplomatic channels—either orally or in writing—in a number of different ways and at different levels of intensity. Hitherto, I think the understanding of what constituted a protest was that which was defined as such at the time that it was made, or which in some other way had that character very clearly about it.

Expressions of concern are a lesser form of diplomatic communication. They are very common in this business, again, at varying levels of intensity, and it is really a matter of semantic choice as to how one chooses to go about it. I repeat that, until Dr Mahathir responded as he did, we were genuinely and sincerely of the view that the communications that we had received on this matter had been pitched—indeed, deliberately—at a level short of what we would formally understand as being a diplomatic protest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In those circumstances, why did the formal release put out on 2 December make no mention at all of the fact that, at almost the highest levels, there had been a former protest recorded? Indeed, why did that release seek to convey the impression that the Malaysian authorities were not in any shape or form expressing concern, and that all that needed to be done was to take note of the fact that the Australian government was seeking to respond to problems?

—The fact that Senator Alston derived that impression, or says now that he derived that impression, from the press release is a matter for him. The fact is that we were making the point that there had not been, as we understood it, a formal protest lodged at that time, and we said so. It is not to be assumed from that that there have not been other diplomatic communications. Of course, in the circumstances of the situation, there was likely to be—and anyone who knew anything about the nature of diplomatic dialogue would have assumed that there would have been some communication about it, and certainly something in the nature of expressions of concern.

PARA.TAB: I cannot account for Senator Alston's ignorance of these matters. I do my best to understand it. What I have difficulty in understanding, however, is his attitude, that of Senator Hill and that of the opposition generally, towards the handling of this matter. This is a difficult national problem with which we are confronted and it would help a great deal if there was a united national approach to its resolution whereby its solution was encouraged and assisted. Instead, we have this hypocritical tirade that we are now hearing.

I remind the Senate that at the time of Mr Keating's original remark in Seattle there were expressions of understanding from those opposite. What has changed except the political wind and their own lousy, rotten, grubby sense of political opportunism? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Arts and Administrative Services. My question relates to the launch tomorrow in Fremantle of the replica of Captain Cook's ship, the HM Bark Endeavour. What role, if any, will the Commonwealth play in bringing this project to its completion? What future role will the Commonwealth play in the operation of this important and descriptive piece of Australia's maritime heritage?

—This is a very appropriate question for a Western Australian senator to raise because it has been an important activity in Western Australia for a number of years. I think it is something to be welcomed by all Australians and all honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: This project has been an outstanding construction effort. It has been described as the finest example of an 18th century replica vessel in existence anywhere in the world. The project has come to fruition through the generosity and untiring efforts of the HM Bark Endeavour foundation, the Endeavour Foundation. These efforts have been supported by the original generosity of the Bond Corporation, ongoing advice from the National Maritime Museum and substantial financial assistance from the Commonwealth government and the New South Wales government, for which I am grateful, as well as from money raised through a public appeal.

The original inspiration was derived from the trustees of the National Maritime Museum, so the Commonwealth has been involved since the origin of the proposal. When it was taken up by the Bond Corporation, the original intention was to make the Australian National Maritime Museum's wharf at Darling Harbour the ship's home port. It was subsequently transferred by deed of gift to the Endeavour Foundation in 1991. The foundation was established expressly for the purpose of overseeing the completion of the vessel with a view, pursuant to its deed of trust, to gifting it to the nation through the Australian National Maritime Museum.

On that basis—that is, on the basis that it would be gifted to the nation through the National Maritime Museum—a rescue package was negotiated between the Commonwealth and the Endeavour Foundation in August 1991. I want to congratulate the now Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, who played a key part in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current Treasurer.
—Yes; that is right. I am saying that because he was not the Treasurer when he did it. Does Senator Alston understand English or is he as dumb about that as he is about foreign policy?

PARA.TAB: The situation is that on the same terms—that is, on the terms that this would be gifted to the nation—the Commonwealth agreed to grant tax deductibility status for the trust. On that basis, the New South Wales government provided a grant of $750,000 to the project. There has been very close cooperation between the federal government and the New South Wales government. In fact, I discussed it briefly with Minister Collins this morning.

Tomorrow afternoon's celebration in Fremantle would not be happening without the enthusiasm and the generosity of a large number of workers, supporters and generous patrons, and all deserve sincere congratulations—the Treasurer for his early recognition of the historical importance of the undertaking and the other significant donors and members of the foundation.

I am very much looking forward to the day when, as a result of the collective efforts of all those people, the cooperative effort between the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments and the support of many citizens, the Endeavour comes to Sydney and is moored at the National Maritime Museum's wharf as an ongoing asset to the education about and recognition of Australia's culture and heritage. I thank all those who have been associated with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasury annual report for 1992-93, which was released yesterday. In it we find that the 17 staff members now attached to the Foreign Investment Review Board each had to process 250 foreign investment applications last year compared with 160 for each staffer in the previous year and 35 just a decade ago. At the same time, they collectively had to answer some 40,000 phone inquiries and were also supposed to follow up on the more than 1,900 approvals that were issued with conditions attached in the previous year. Can the minister give a guarantee, with staff spending less and less time on each application, that foreign investment proposals are being properly evaluated, especially with regard to whether they are contrary to the national interest, which is the criterion the government applies to them?

—Notwithstanding that I am the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Senate would be stunned to know that I have not actually read the Treasury annual report. It is a terrible confession to have to make and I very sincerely regret it. I am sure every other senator has and I am apologetic for letting down the 75 who so industriously read it. We will ask questions about it after question time.

PARA.TAB: I did not know that those figures were in the annual report, but I accept them as being an accurate reflection of what is there. The figures reflect, as I am sure Senator Kernot would agree, the very industrious and hardworking nature of the officers in question. I think it is appropriate to put that on the record from time to time since we only talk about public servants in here when we criticise them. I like to have the opportunity to say how well and diligently these people work.

I am not aware of any expressions of concern by any staff of the Foreign Investment Review Board that the current staffing arrangements are not sufficient to enable them to discharge their obligations under the act. They are very responsible people. If they were concerned, they would have made it clear. I am not aware of any. To the best of my knowledge, there have not been any. If that is not correct, I will come back to the Senate. But that is my understanding.

The decade comparison is not particularly relevant because the nature of scrutiny of foreign investment review proposals has changed as the law has changed over the last decade, but that cannot explain the difference over the last year. I think the explanation of the difference is the significant increase in interest in investment in Australia over the last 12 months, which I greatly welcome. I think it is a very positive situation that more and more people are interested in investing in this country. That is how we are going to create more jobs. If there is anything the Treasurer wishes to add, I will report back to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The flow of foreign investment is on the rise again. The minister says that he welcomes that. I welcome that with our strings attached. Even if staff are just giving it the big tick as usual, does the minister really think there are going to be enough staff to cope adequately with the follow-up on approvals issued with conditions attached? How can they properly monitor these conditions with so few people?

—It is always the case that with more staff all departments and agencies could do more, but the tax base would go up as we employed a lot more people. I do not think to put more resources in here is the most cost-effective use of the taxpayer's dollar. I would be pleased to be in the situation where there was so much interest in investment in Australia that we had to employ more people to look at it. That would be a very welcome situation. It would mean we were creating more jobs. I think that is the primary concern of all senators, and certainly of the government.

PARA.TAB: There is an agreed staffing level for the Treasury. It has allocated its staff to, amongst others, the Foreign Investment Review Board. I know some of the officers concerned. They are very skilled and capable officers. They have not expressed any concern about being unable to discharge their statutory obligations. As I said before, if the Treasurer has some other concern, I will come back and report it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I note the support by the Commonwealth government for the construction of the Glebe Island Bridge in Sydney, which will act as a gateway to the Homebush Olympic site and also relieve a lot of traffic congestion in that area. Can the minister advise the Senate of the progress that has been made towards the completion of this vital infrastructure development?

—I am pleased to say that this is an extremely important construction project for the city of Sydney. It will, in fact, be the primary transport link between the Sydney central business district and the Homebush Bay Olympic venue. The construction of this bridge was a vital part of the transport infrastructure plan which was included in the winning Sydney 2000 Olympic bid.

PARA.TAB: The bridge, scheduled for completion in 1998, will overcome the very severe traffic congestion which is currently being experienced between Pyrmont and Balmain. As well as allowing a smooth flow of traffic to Homebush Bay and the suburbs around Parramatta, it will greatly improve road freight access to Sydney's inner ports. The total cost of the project is $150 million. The six-lane bridge will extend 800 metres between two towers, which will rise 120 metres above water level.

As well as providing an essential link to the Olympic venue and easing traffic congestion, it will add very significantly to the visual amenity of Sydney. It will be a magnificent structure from an engineering point of view. In fact, it will be the first major concrete cable-stayed bridge constructed in Australia. Of course, the most prominent international example of this type of bridge is the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.

The Commonwealth has strongly supported this project from the beginning because we have understood the significance of the construction of this bridge to the Olympic bid for Sydney. To date, the Commonwealth has contributed $66 million toward the construction of the bridge. I am pleased to advise the Senate that I have today approved additional funding of $24 million for further works on the Glebe Island Bridge. This will bring the total Commonwealth contribution to this project—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a Labor electorate?

—It is in the electorate of Sydney, which is a Labor electorate, and it actually feeds into a number of other Labor electorates. I think the transport minister, Mr Baird, will be extremely pleased about the additional $24 million that I have provided him with this morning.

PARA.TAB: These extra funds were provided from within this year's allocation for the national arterial roads in New South Wales. The reason we were able to provide them is that savings that were made on other national arterial projects have freed up over $35 million, which can now be spent on additional works in New South Wales. I think that this supports the comment that I made to Senator Short the other day in a debate on the Auditor-General's report that the Commonwealth is effectively concentrating on getting the best possible results in terms of outputs from our road program. The city of Sydney will benefit significantly from this additional $24 million that was injected into the project this morning.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The minister will be aware of reports that a Brisbane based architectural firm, McKerrell Lynch, has lost a $1 million contract with Malaysia because of the Prime Minister's failure to understand or accept the sensitivities of our Asian neighbours. I ask whether the minister agrees with these public statements by the Managing Director of McKerrell Lynch:

QUESTION.PARA: Anything that Australians are involved in currently in Malaysia would have to be under jeopardy.
How many more Australian businesses will have to lose contracts with Malaysia before the Prime Minister will make a genuine attempt to rectify the impasse his gratuitous insult has created?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Prime Minister has made a genuine attempt to resolve the impasse over this matter. He has made it perfectly clear that he had no intention to cause offence. From comments made in his letter and from subsequent public statements—in particular, on the Sunday program last weekend—the message that is being conveyed by the Prime Minister, very clearly and unequivocally, to Malaysia is that he had no intention to cause any offence and that, if any offence was taken, he regrets that. No reasonable further step can be asked of the Prime Minister. No statement can be asked of him that goes further than that, in the circumstances of the case. I say again that we regret very much, obviously, the damage that is being done to Australian firms, businesses, consultancies. We regret very much the further damage that may be caused if this matter is not capable of resolution.
—Yesterday you said that business would have to put up with it.

—That is when I was asked about what we were going to do by way of providing compensation or financial support. Do I take it from Senator Hill that the opposition is making some kind of commitment to give financial compensation to all those who might be affected by matters of this kind? Is that what I am to take from the opposition? Of course not, because the opposition would never make any such commitment, and nor did I yesterday. Of course we are doing our best to resolve this situation in all the ways that I have mentioned. What I continue to find very difficult to understand in this respect is the fact that the opposition spokesmen and backbenchers asking questions about this can be—
—You've trotted this out three days running and got nowhere.
—Senator Alston, please cease interjecting.

—I find it difficult to understand that opposition spokesmen and backbenchers can be as raucous as they are on this subject now when they were as understanding as they were when the matter first became a public issue on 23 November. The Age of 23 November reported:

PARA.TAB: The shadow foreign minister, Mr Peacock, said he could easily make capital from Mr Keating's statements, but in view of Dr Mahathir's attitude leading up to the APEC meeting, the remarks were understandable.

ANSWER.PARA: A spokeswoman for Mr Peacock said that Mr Peacock understood Mr Keating's frustration with Dr Mahathir and knew that `straight talking is sometimes a good thing'. A spokesman for the National Party leader, Mr Fischer, also supported Mr Keating. Well, if straight talking was a good thing at that stage, what has changed? When does straight talking cease to be a good thing? The short answer is: when the opposition thinks there is some political value, some vote to be gained, by taking a different attitude. Look at those opposite, they have the political morals of a bunch of alley cats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Prime Minister, at the very least, have the good grace to apologise to the Australians who have lost their businesses, particularly those who will have lost their jobs because of the loose mouth of the Prime Minister?

—I have said, and no doubt the Prime Minister will find an opportunity to say, how regrettable the state of affairs is as it presently exists, and as it may further develop unless this situation can be resolved. I only ask that, in our efforts to resolve this situation, we get some cooperation from the opposition and not the kind of carping, opportunistic negativism that it has made so obviously its own.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Office of Multicultural Affairs: Poster Series

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Multicultural Affairs. I refer to the `Images of Australia' poster series produced by the Office of Multicultural Affairs. Firstly, what is the purpose of this initiative? Secondly, how many posters have been produced and what steps are being taken to carry this campaign further?

—I thank my colleague Senator Collins for his advice in answering this question. The question that Senator Jones raised is one that relates to a project by the Office of Multicultural Affairs which has already developed into a major success though it is relatively new. The project is one which, through poster form, through the avenue of the visual image, aims to reflect in a very simple and vivid way different aspects of Australia's unique cultural diversity. The government's position, of course, is that one of the major resources of this country is the diversity of our people.

PARA.TAB: As any educator or advertiser would know, visual image is a highly effective and powerful way of getting across a positive message to the widest possible audience. In that respect, the poster series is aimed at getting across to as many people as possible the resources that we have and possess as a nation because of our diversity.

The series started last year. The first poster was an artwork done by the Aboriginal artist Sally Morgan. The poster was commissioned by OMA and was launched in May 1992 by Minister Hand. A sign of the success of the project is that some 10,000 copies of the poster were produced. They presented a quite vivid image of our Aboriginal heritage and, of course, the vital contribution that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are continuing to make to our society. The posters have proved enormously popular not only with community groups but with individuals throughout the country.

Yesterday I had the opportunity to launch the second poster of the series at the National Gallery of Australia. This time the artwork was the work of the well-known artist Salvatore Zofrea, who migrated to Australia with his family from southern Italy in 1956. Once again, the same number of posters will be produced and made available from the Office of Multicultural Affairs.

As well as launching the poster and pushing this particular series to raise our society's awareness of our diversity and the resources that we have through that diversity, I was also able to present the original watercolour of Salvatore Zofrea's work to the Director of the National Gallery of Australia, Betty Churcher. That particular work depicts, as one would imagine, not only the participation of non-English speaking background European migrants to Australia but also how much and how many of their cultures they have brought with them and how those cultures have now been factored in to become very much part of Australia's everyday way of life.

The other important outcome of yesterday's exercise was to locate in one of our national and cultural institutions—the National Gallery of Australia—an item which once again continues to develop within that gallery a reflection of the diversity in our society. Australian people have been successful in developing a multicultural society. This poster enhances what we are doing. Our aim is to promote the resources which are available for our development as a nation—those resources being located in our diversity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
—They have got out the heavy artillery now.

—Bright spark! He could not make a sensible interjection if he tried. Is it a fact that the minister was not involved in the preparation of the Prime Minister's letter to Dr Mahathir and that, although the junior minister, Senator Cook, sighted it, the minister was not asked to approve the final draft of what he now calls a genuine attempt to apologise? Does he support the Prime Minister's claim that the Malaysian leadership was feigning anger over his remarks in Seattle? Why has he, as foreign minister, been effectively sidelined? What steps has he taken to get the Australian-Malaysian relationship back on track?

—I am not prepared to comment on this or any other occasion as to the course of advice or communications between me or other ministers and the Prime Minister in the preparation of material of this kind. It has never been a matter for disclosure in this place, and it never will be as far as I am concerned. That is the way the case will be and no inference either way should be drawn from that.

PARA.TAB: So far as my personal role in this is concerned, obviously I was very closely involved in tracking and dealing with the issues and in working out an appropriate response before I went away to Vietnam and Papua New Guinea. Obviously, I have been closely involved in it since. In the first answer I gave today, I indicated what I had been doing this morning. As to further detail, I am sorry, the opposition is not getting any.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the minister agree with the United Nations resolution yesterday that no progress has been made in Burma towards the restoration of democracy or in the reduction of human rights abuses? Does the minister support the proposal by the United States for the appointment of a special envoy on Burma to supplement human rights fact-finding missions, prevent arms from reaching the military and ensure that aid moneys do not enrich the government or the army? Finally, is the government taking any action to encourage the United Nations to remove the representative of the SLORC from the UN seat currently held by Burma and replace him with a representative of the democratically elected government?

—The resolution on human rights in Burma, which was adopted by consensus on 6 December, as Senator Bourne has said, by the third committee of the UN General Assembly underlines the international community's very grave concern at the continuing failure of the Burmese government to move towards democracy and the continued seriousness of the human rights situation in that country. Australia was one of the co-sponsors of the resolution. We were closely involved in its drafting and in seeking support for its adoption.

PARA.TAB: The resolution calls on the SLORC to take all necessary steps towards the restoration of democracy and to ensure full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It also calls for the unconditional release of opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, regrets the recent harsh sentences meted out to a number of dissidents and stresses the importance of free and confidential access to prisoners by international humanitarian agencies.

The resolution recognises that there has been some limited progress in Burma, as I have said in this place from time to time, including the release of political prisoners and the signing of a memorandum of understanding: for example, on 5 November this year with the UN High Commissioner for Refugees covering arrangements for the repatriation of the Rohingya refugees. Although such developments are welcome, they are clearly quite insufficient to allay concerns over the political and human rights situation.

We are particularly concerned that a very significant number of people remain in gaol or detention for political activities and that the SLORC has demonstrated so little willingness to accommodate democratic aspirations through the national convention process. I have made these concerns clear directly to Burmese authorities on a number of occasions, as of course have our representatives and as I have indeed in this place as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your position on an arms embargo?

—I will come to that. The United States, to answer Senator Bourne's second question, joined the consensus to adopt the resolution but did not co-sponsor it. This position reflected a feeling on the part of the US that the resolution should have appointed a special envoy to supplement the mandate of the UN special rapporteur, Professor Yokota, called for a voluntary arms embargo and urged UN agencies to ensure funding does not support the SLORC. While Australia would have been prepared to co-sponsor a resolution containing these additional points—we had no problem with any of them—we accepted that such a resolution stood little chance of being adopted by consensus, and adoption by consensus is important in the UN third committee context in that it sends a very clear signal to the SLORC about the breadth of international concern over the situation in Burma, including on the part of countries within its own region. Otherwise that message gets diluted if we accommodate some of these other concerns.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill is demonstrating his usual profound and total and irredeemable ignorance and insensitivity about these matters. It would be better for all concerned, including his reputation, if he simply shut up on these occasions.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government has consistently supported moves to redirect UN assistance, specifically that provided by UNDP, away from longer term development objectives in favour of support for humanitarian activities, which are designed to help the Burmese people at the grassroots level. The Australian government has its own embargoes on the export of defence and defence related goods to Burma—I told Senator Hill I would answer that bit—and it has urged countries known to supply arms to Burma to discontinue such exports. As to the final part of Senator Bourne's three-part question, the Australian government's policy is to recognise states not governments. This policy is consistent with the practice of most other major Western countries. We recognise the state of Burma and, thus, we support its right to a seat at the UN. That does not in any way imply Australian government approval of the policies of the SLORC or the manner by which it attained and retains power.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What value does the government place on the Australian Heritage Commission's assessment of high conservation value forests? What is the government's official interpretation of the moratorium clause in the national forest policy statement?

—The government, Senator Chamarette perhaps will not be surprised to hear, highly values the advice given by the Australian Heritage Commission and notes the statutory requirement that the government not take any action that may adversely affect a place listed on the register of the National Estate unless there is no prudent and feasible alternative.

PARA.TAB: As to our official interpretation of the moratorium clause in the national forest policy, the agreed approach under the national forest policy statement to the conservation of old growth forests and wilderness areas has five elements as follows: firstly, agreed criteria for the protection of old growth and wilderness areas are to be determined by a technical working group on reserves established under the NFPS. These are expected to be finalised by early next year. Secondly, state agencies will use these criteria to assess the conservation value of forests. Thirdly, until the assessments are completed, forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value. Fourthly, wilderness areas and old growth areas will be protected by reserves and complementary management outside of reserves. Fifthly, management plans will be used to protect old growth forest and wilderness values.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government intend, therefore, to enforce the moratorium referred to in sections 3 and 5 that have just been read out? If not, of what use is the national forest policy?

—I have no information whatever in front of me or knowledge which would suggest that we are not going to enforce the criteria along the lines that I have just indicated. If the Prime Minister has anything further that he wants to add, then I will be delighted to add it, but I cannot understand what the basis for that question might be.

—Because of my role—a very useful one—in upgrading the standard of maritime vessels in Australia, I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to Australia's participation in regional efforts to coordinate and share information from each country's ship inspection program. Can the minister advise of progress being made in this area to improve the compliance of the world shipping fleet with international safety standards?

—I thank Senator Burns for that question on behalf of the workers. I am pleased to advise that a meeting of maritime authorities in Tokyo last week agreed to a memorandum of understanding which will substantially improve cooperation and the control of substandard shipping in the Asia-Pacific region. The development of this agreement has been encouraged by the International Maritime Organisation under its 1991 resolution which invited member governments to consider concluding regional cooperative arrangements aimed at sharing ship inspection data and promoting a more comprehensive and harmonised ship inspection regime as a result.

PARA.TAB: Such regional agreements already exist between 15 European coastal states and 10 Latin American countries. This represents the culmination of a relatively lengthy period of consultation between the 17 signatories in which Australia, I am pleased to say, has taken a leading role. It will result in the implementation and enforcement of more stringent and uniform ship inspection standards and emphasise the importance of training for regional ship surveyors and inspectors. It also provides for information to be exchanged between participating states and with countries participating in the European agreement.

Australia was closely involved in developing, as I have advised the Senate before, a computer link database to be operated by the Canadian coastguard for the electronic transfer of ship inspection data which can be accessed and updated by participating states. The ultimate aim is to achieve a combined regional annual inspection rate by the year 2000 of 50 per cent of all foreign merchant ships operating in this region. An independent regional secretariat will be established in Tokyo.

Australia took the initiative in hosting an interim secretariat in Melbourne to facilitate the development of these regional cooperation arrangements. The participating states in this agreement that has now been concluded include Canada, China, Fiji, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, the Russian Federation, Singapore, the Solomon Islands, Thailand and Vietnam. This agreement tells the international maritime community very clearly that unsafe vessels are being targeted in the Asia-Pacific region. It represents a very important step towards the ultimate aim of ridding the world of unsafe shipping.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Can the minister inform the Senate of the plans the government has made for Australia's participation in the fourth United Nations World Conference for Women to be held in Beijing in 1995?

This council replaces the old National Women's Consultative Council, and its main function will serve as a focal point for planning and coordinating Australia's activities relating to the fourth United Nations conference on women in Beijing in 1995.

PARA.TAB: The main functions of that council will be to provide expert advice to the government on the most effective and strategic means of preparing for that conference and providing feedback—particularly to non-government organisations—on government planning for the conference. Secondly, that committee will liaise with all community sectors, including the non-government organisations, academia, the private sector, the media and the public. Thirdly, it will assist non-government organisations to provide high quality advice to government on how best to prepare for the world conference.

The council comprises 13 members. It will be chaired by Sandra Yates, and the deputy chair will be Kaye Loder. It draws representation from a group of women—13 members strong—who have been selected for their particular expertise in addressing those priority functions of the council.

Very importantly, what we saw in times past was the non-government organisations, in their preparation for the Nairobi conference, often seeming to work side by side but not in complete cooperation with government, or government not in complete cooperation with the NGOs. There was a gap between those two organisations. This is not to be understood as a requirement that NGOs and government march to the same tune, but they have an opportunity to be assisted.
Senator Vanstone interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone has completely misunderstood what I am saying. Let me make it clear: non-government organisations do not have access to considerable resources. There are so many opportunities presenting themselves for women around the world in the Beijing conference of 1995 that this government certainly does not want to overlook them. —On 6 December, Senator Calvert asked me about landcare funding. The response is as follows: the community grants components of the save the bush and the one billion trees programs are part of the national landcare program—NLP. Applications for each grant under the NLP are called for early in the calendar year and the closing date is late March, early April.

PARA.TAB: Applications are initially assessed by regional program-based assessment panels with a majority of community members, followed by assessments through a state assessment panel. In the case of the STB and the OBT programs, the SAP recommendations are forwarded to the Australian Nature Conservation Agency which forwards the recommendations to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) for her consideration and approval. Announcement of successful applicants is usually made in September.

A total of 414 projects were approved under the combined community grants components of STB-OBT programs for 1993-94. Out of this total number of projects the minister's office has received two calls from successful applicants seeking information on the availability of funds. The ANCA received approximately 10 calls on the same issue.

The government is aware of concerns regarding the administration of funds to community organisations and the seasonal nature of approved projects. As with most government programs the administration of funds is dependent on the annual budget timetable. The government has not politicised the $7 million landcare funding at the expense of the environment. A summary of the administrative processes for STB and OBT is outlined above.

The programs are community based and community driven. The funding for the environment portfolio component of the NLP community grants funding for 1993-94 is STB, $1.25 million and OBT, $905,000, making a total of $215 million. It should be noted that, for the 1993-94 financial year, 63 per cent of funds under the OBT community grants program went to coalition electorates. The corresponding figure for STB was 54 per cent. The answer to paragraph (d) of the question is as above.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday, Senator MacGibbon asked a question about defence contingency planning in relation to North Korea. I have additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question. As my colleague Senator Evans said on Monday, it is to be hoped that there will be a peaceful resolution of the North Korean nuclear issue. The United States, South Korea and the International Atomic Energy Agency are all involved in delicate negotiations with North Korea aimed at ensuring it complies fully with its obligations.

PARA.TAB: But in the event of North Korean military action against South Korea, it would primarily be for South Korean and United States military forces to respond and defend South Korea. A United States-South Korea combined forces command was established in 1978. Recent statements by President Clinton and United States Defense Secretary Aspin have reinforced the United States commitment to the defence of South Korea.

There is no contingency plan for Australian military action if North Korea persists in not cooperating with the provisions of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Nevertheless, the Department of Defence is paying careful attention to all aspects of the situation on the Korean peninsula.

The United Nations command in Korea, set up by the United Nations Security Council in 1950 during the Korean War, remains in place. Although an armistice agreement was signed in 1953, no permanent political settlement has subsequently been reached. Australia is a member of the United Nations command. The Australian defence attache in Seoul is accredited to the United Nations command as Australian liaison officer.

United Nations Security Council action to date has been directed at encouraging North Korean compliance with the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and its safeguards obligations to the International Atomic Energy Agency. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs said in his answer on 6 December 1993, there are many steps to go through before the matter would again be referred to the United Nations Security Council.

I did not, as your article claims, mention contributing to Richard Court's leadership. I referred to my modest contribution to his premiership, a distinction not too subtle for most.

Your account of Withers and McLean going north with membership lists and discovering "there were dead people, people who'd left town years ago, branches that never existed" is a total fabrication. It is not without significance that the source of the concoction is not named. The reason for that is all too obvious. The article implies that the proposition was put to me by the author but of course that is simply not true.

The article makes much of the Floreat State seat election without even an elementary understanding of events. Dr Constable was assured success at the last election, when the Liberal Party endorsed 64 year old Dr Jecks, a circumstance caused by one of the largest constitutional Liberal branches in the electorate being disqualified from sitting on the pre-selection, occasioned by the failure of the branch to provide the State Director with the branch's pre-selection delegates within the prescribed time.

Your reference to the former Liberal Senator Sim ignores the fact that, after 16 years of accepting Liberal Party endorsement, he supported Dr Constable in both the bi-election and general election against the endorsed Liberal candidate. He has not for some time been a member of the Liberal Party.
Finally, your reference to suggestions that I used a private trust to win favour with branches through gift membership is both utterly untrue and libellous.
Yours sincerely

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to ask you a question about certain conduct in the chamber this morning.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am wondering whether you are aware of the incident that occurred in the chamber this morning when two of Senator Crowley's ministerial advisers actually took part in the debate, one by comment and the other at various times by facial expression.
—A facial expression?

—Senator Carr has just made an idiotic interjection. Normally, political, ministerial or shadow ministerial advisers on both sides of the chamber do not take part in the debate, make comments or make snide remarks about what is said on one side of the chamber, as happened this morning.
—Or show facial expressions!
—That is all right. I wish we could bring Senator Button back some time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Panizza, ask the question.

—Mr President, if you are aware of what happened, what are you doing about it? To my knowledge, this is the third time it has happened in this chamber this year. It has happened to me. I have picked them up in the course of my speech and they have certainly cut it out. Are you investigating the matter or have you investigated it and, if there has been a misdemeanour, what will you do about it?

—This matter was referred to me over the lunch break, so I was able to prepare a statement. During debate on the motion of disallowance relating to the child-care guidelines, it was alleged by opposition senators that an adviser in the ministerial advisers benches had directed an interjection to opposition senators.

PARA.TAB: I make it clear that any such behaviour by advisers in the advisers benches or by any person in any of the galleries is grossly disorderly and the chair may order the withdrawal or removal of any offenders. Past rulings on this matter are referred to at page 951 of Australian Senate Practice. Advisers who are assisting senators from the advisers benches have a particular obligation to behave with complete decorum.

Senator West, who was in the chair at the time, indicated that she did not believe that the adviser concerned had behaved in the manner suggested, and of course I am not able to say whether the incident occurred as alleged because at the time I was chairing a meeting of the Australian Political Exchange Committee. I am simply ruling on a question of principle.

During the same debate it was suggested that I should rule on a request made to Senator Herron that he withdraw a statement to the effect that Senator Crowley had made misleading statements. The relevant principle here is that senators must not make statements in debate which assert or imply that another senator has deliberately or knowingly made untrue statements. Rulings of past presidents and rulings made by Deputy President Colston, as he then was, on 15 October 1991 and by me on 9 December 1992 have made this quite clear. Statements that other senators' statements are not true or misleading are not necessarily out of order; for the chair to intervene there must be some implication that a senator has deliberately or knowingly made untrue statements. It is for the chair to judge whether this implication is present in any particular instance. The questions referred to me by Senator Panizza are matters for the chair and I hope that this ruling is taken note of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on that matter I seek your advice as to the procedure that should be followed. If an adviser interjects as occurred, what is the mechanism for drawing it to the attention of the chair, who in this case apparently was unable to see what occurred? It was drawn to the chair's attention at the time. I certainly will not tolerate that again and I seek your advice as to how that should be counteracted in future.

—It is a matter for the chair to decide. When the chair is informed of the circumstances the chair should act, and I am hoping that as a result of the statement I have made today the same circumstances do not arise in the future.
—Is it within the right of the chair to eject that person from the chamber?
—Yes, it is, and I have made that clear in the statement. It is like clearing somebody out of the gallery.
—I seek leave to make a comment on your statement, Mr President.
—You can seek leave, but I thought I had covered it fairly comprehensively.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, having listened to your statement, I want to say that I was in the chamber at the time. I was sitting where Senator McGauran sits. I saw that adviser interjecting across the chamber. I am not trying to lay any blame on Senator West who was in the chair, because she was looking the other way and could not see what was going on at that particular time. But it is important, when these things are drawn to the attention of the chair—as this was by a number of people on this side of the chamber—that the adviser at least be informed by the chair that such behaviour is out of order and be asked to desist immediately. I do not believe that occurred today and I think the behaviour here was quite unsatisfactory and quite unnecessary.
