TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill from moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence over all other business to a motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in relation to relations with Malaysia.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion to censure the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in relation to relations with Malaysia may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his failure to take appropriate action to prevent the increasing and continuing damage to Australia's relations with Malaysia, Australia's standing in Asia and Australia's significant trade with Malaysia, arising from his intemperate remarks concerning the Malaysian Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion today more in sorrow than in anger. But it is the view of this side of the chamber that the Senate must protest the action taken by the Prime Minister, which has resulted in severe and ongoing damage to Australia's interests—particularly to Australian business interests, which have been working for years in a difficult environment to build trade and investment links with Malaysia.

PARA.TAB: In the last few days we have put before the Senate a whole series of complaints that have come in from concerned Australian businesses. I mention just a few of them without going through the details again: McKerrell Lynch, Champion Compressors Ltd of Victoria, SEAS Sapfor of South Australia, Voxson International of Brisbane, Jakab Industries of Tamworth, AWA industries, major power generation projects in Malaysia, soft furnishings interests, and Bufori Motor Company of Sydney. I could go on.

Our faxes are running hot—no doubt Minister Evans's fax is running hot as well—from complaints by Australian business men and women who are distraught about the damage that is being caused to their interests as a result of the irresponsible statements by the Prime Minister. It is a demonstration of his arrogance and ineptitude. He is an ego driven Prime Minister who put that ego ahead of Australia's interests and in Seattle decided, because he thought he had done pretty well out of the APEC conference, that it was time to take a slash at the Malaysian Prime Minister. It was totally gratuitous, as I said the other day. It was a gratuitous indulgence that has done nothing but cause harm to Australia's interests, and for that he should be condemned.

Furthermore, he and his government should be condemned for the fact that they have taken so little constructive action since that default in trying to put the situation right. We would not be moving in this direction today if we had seen constructive, positive action from the Prime Minister, and from his Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), subsequent to this stupidity to try to put the matter right. But we simply have not seen that occur.

As I said, the Senate cannot stand by today and simply watch Australia's relationship with Malaysia deteriorate. It particularly cannot stand by and watch Australia's business interests in Malaysia suffer without voicing its protest in the strongest terms. I remind you, Mr President, that this is the Prime Minister who said that it is in Australia's interest to engage Asia. This is the Prime Minister who said that it is in our interest to be accepted as part of Asia. He is the Prime Minister who said that this was a principal goal of his government. Yet we see this evidence of a total lack of understanding of the sensitivities relating to the region as demonstrated by him in Seattle.

Perhaps it should not come to us as a surprise because this was the Prime Minister who went to Indonesia and apologised for our constitution and the flag. This was the Prime Minister who said overseas, in the region, that we had to modify our attitude to human rights to fit within the region. Yet this is the Prime Minister who so conversely, nevertheless, feels that he can get away with a bit of personal abuse against the Prime Minister of one of our regional neighbours simply because it suits his political purpose of the moment. Reckless, insensitive, stupid: all these words must apply to the action that the Prime Minister took.

I understand that the Prime Minister is disappointed about Malaysia's attitude to APEC. The facts are that Malaysia has a different point of view. It believes in the development of an Asian organisation and that that would be of greater benefit to Malaysia than APEC. We have a different point of view because we would be excluded from this Asian organisation. We believe that, if we could link Asia with North America in particular, then that is more to Australia's benefit. Both are legitimate points of view. So it is quite reasonable for the Prime Minister to be disappointed that the Malaysian Prime Minister did not turn up at Seattle.

But what should he do about that? He can, obviously, if he had any sense at all, take the diplomatic path and try to work towards engaging Malaysia within the project that he sees as of Australia's interest, and so do we—encouraging Malaysia. As Senator O'Chee will know, the next meeting of the leaders of APEC was to be held in Indonesia and, because of the solidarity of ASEAN, there was every possibility that the Malaysian Prime Minister would attend in any event. So within a year or so there could have been a positive move in a direction that would benefit Australia. But what has he done? He has ruined all opportunity of that occurring, and that is appalling.

Having made a statement that could only be seen as damaging Australia's interests, what action did we then see from either Mr Keating or Senator Evans? The first reaction, of course, was to simply dismiss it. When it was put that Dr Mahathir would have been disappointed with his attitude, the Prime Minister's response was, `He is in the business of feigned indignation'. How would that help a problem that was already on the table? Again, it is a typical response of Prime Minister Keating. He should have recognised that he needed to be conciliatory and that he had been in error—and hopefully his Foreign Minister was telling him that he was in error, that the relationship with Malaysia had always been a tricky one and it was in our interest to demonstrate sensitivity. That is what they do not seem to understand—it is in our interest to demonstrate sensitivity in building that relationship because we are seeking to gain advantage from that relationship. But instead of recognising that need to be conciliatory, he took another slash at the Malaysian Prime Minister and suggested that it was simply a case of feigned indignation.

What was the response of the Australian Foreign Minister? It seems in the first instance that there was not simply any response at all. It is astonishing to those of us on this side of the table that it has taken until now before the Australian Foreign Minister has been prepared to pick up the phone and ring his counterpart in Malaysia and say, `We have to find a way through this problem'. It is disgraceful that the problem has to wait until all of these Australian businesses complain that they are now losing contracts and losing opportunities—today we heard that business visas are not being granted—before the Australian Foreign Minister is prepared to get on the phone and see whether he can do something about it. As I said, we really find this a depressing situation. If the Australian government had taken action after the stupid comments of Mr Keating and genuinely sought to put the situation right, we would not be here moving this censure motion today.

Mr President, I draw your attention to the press release that the spokesman for the Prime Minister put out on 2 December 1993. This was the statement issued after the Prime Minister had apparently written a letter to the Malaysian Prime Minister. In effect, in this statement he implies that it is equally Malaysia's responsibility to sort this problem out as it is Australia's. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Both Governments need to avoid a situation in which the media is setting the tone . . . We hope that both Governments will act in a way which clearly draws a line . . .

He is not recognising that he is at fault and saying, `I acknowledge that and I now want to put the relationship right again'. He is saying, `It's the other side's fault as much as it's mine'. Mr Deputy President, did you see the explanation? It said:
The Prime Minister's remarks in Seattle were not calculated to give offence to Dr Mahathir.
Very good. It then goes on to say:

Rather, they were made to make clear that it was a decision for Malaysia, and Dr Mahathir, if Malaysia wished to absent itself from the APEC meeting and that Australia had clear design interests in the architecture of APEC, interests which it would defend vigorously.

What he is trying to do is explain away his personal abuse by saying that we have a right to defend our interests in APEC. That is not the way in which we seek to defend our interests in APEC. Even Mr Keating, I would have thought, should have known that—and, above all, Senator Evans should have known it. But Senator Evans has mysteriously kept out of it from the start. In effect, he was not prepared to say that he had done anything at all, until yesterday. Today, finally, under all the pressure, he is prepared to pick up the phone. Why has not the Australian Foreign Minister sought to help and get Australia through this very difficult situation?

PARA.TAB: We have agreed to a strict time limit of 10 minutes each and my time is just about up. As I said, we have moved this motion because we think it is important that the Senate registers its protest. It is important that the Senate say to the Prime Minister and his government that their conduct in this matter has been appalling, that they have let Australian interests down and that they must now do something about it. Instead of Prime Minister Keating locking himself away in his room and hoping that this problem will go away, he must genuinely do something about bringing it to an end. Unless we add our voice to the Australian business people who are suffering so much as a result of Prime Minister Keating's ineptitude, it would seem that little is going to be done. I trust the minority parties will support this motion—I know the government will not—and that we will send a clear message to Prime Minister Keating that he has let Australia down and that we now demand action from him to put right what he has done wrong.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a misconceived motion of censure whose timing is absolutely appalling. We have a problem with Malaysia, and that is self-evidently so. Some commercial damage has already been caused as a result of that problem. A good deal more such damage is feared. As a government and as a nation, we are extremely conscious of that, but the point that needs to be appreciated is that we are trying very hard to solve the problem as a government. Diplomatic channels are open—they have never in fact been closed. Ministerial lines of communication are well and truly open through the presence of Senator Ray in Malaysia at the moment and just recently in the case of Senator Cook and through my own communication since I have been back from overseas this week. We are working overtime to try to contain the problem, to resolve it in a mutually acceptable way.

PARA.TAB: The important thing at this stage is to keep the atmosphere cool, not to inflame it. The important thing is to pause for reflection, not for breast beating, angst or political point scoring. This is the kind of point that I have sought to make to my Malaysian colleagues—the virtues of a pause and not to let the situation get inflamed and escalate out of control, as situations such as this so often do if they are contributed to by inflammatory statements. If that is a message that we want to deliver and have accepted and understood on the Malaysian side, it ought to be a message that is capable of being understood, appreciated and accepted on the Australian side. This is not an occasion to be inflaming the debate. It is an occasion for cooling the debate. It is an occasion not for political point scoring but for reflecting on the nature and the value of the relationship that we have with Malaysia and the importance of that relationship not being disturbed.

I do not want to make again the kinds of responses to the opposition's point scoring that I have already made in question time. I think they speak for themselves. The truth of the matter, however, needs to be briefly recalled that at the time that Mr Keating made his remarks in Seattle there was an expression from the opposition side not of outrage, not of indignation, not of belief that something calamitous had potentially happened, but of understanding. Members of the opposition said that this was not the time to be making political capital. They said, `We understand the context in which these remarks were made and, in effect, we could have understood ourselves making them had we been there in that same situation'.

The only thing that has changed since 23 November when those remarks from Mr Peacock and Mr Fischer were reported has been, of course, the fact that over recent days in particular the situation has rather deteriorated with Malaysia. There has been a perceived capacity on the part of the opposition to score a point or two against the government by berating us for all the things that are mentioned in the censure motion. Of course, that initial understanding that was so clearly on the public record about the circumstances of Mr Keating's statement has now totally evaporated in a cacophony of rather crude political abuse and point scoring that we are hearing from the other side. That is a matter for regret.

Foreign policy is best conducted, if it is humanly possible—I know that it is not always—in a spirit of bipartisanship and genuine understanding of what the national interest of this country is. I repeat that the national interest of this country at the moment is not in having a self-indulgent political debate but in having a clear, reflective approach to this issue which effectively communicates to the Malaysian side how much we value this relationship.

I want to make it clear on the record right now how much we value the relationship and all the different component parts of it. We value the defence relationship that has existed for so long. We have always been committed to the security of the country and we have demonstrated that through our involvement in and the reaction to the communist insurgency and by, of course, in years subsequently, our involvement and participation in the five-power defence arrangement. We are committed in the most fundamental way to the future security and existence of that country. We have demonstrated that in the past. We are perfectly prepared to go on demonstrating it in the future.

We are committed to the economic development of the country. For years we have made quite substantial development assistance support available, particularly through the education sector and, more recently, through commercial infrastructure developments as well. We are happy to keep on doing that so long as Malaysia remains a country with disparities in income and has a need for that kind of development support.

We have had a very strong commitment for over 30 years, through programs of one kind or another, to the education, either publicly scholarship supported or through private educational processes, of Malaysian kids coming to this country. More than 100,000 graduates of Australian educational programs are now living in Malaysia. There is an enormous reservoir of personal goodwill on both sides as a result of that heritage, and that is something we want to nourish, support and sustain.Over 85,000 Australians who were actually born in Malaysia are now full-time residents or citizens of this country. That is a contribution to this country that we value and is a product of the value of that fundamental relationship.

Of course, we have these days a very substantial economic relationship with Malaysia. The size of the trade account is over $2 billion. The investment stock is growing all the time, particularly in terms of Australian investment in that country of significant measure, joint venture, or Malaysian activity, in Australia. It has been very much to the benefit of both countries that that economic relationship has developed as it has and, of course, it is a relationship that has been exploding in intensity and value and in the nature of the commitment over time.

It is a matter for reflection not just on the Australian side as to what will be lost in commercial and economic terms if our relationship should now deteriorate. It is also a matter for appropriate reflection on the Malaysian side. A point that needs to be borne in mind by our Malaysian counterparts as they consider their reaction to these circumstances is just what the implications of allowing this situation to further deteriorate will be. The Malaysians may lose future Australian investment, which is the kind of thing they have been very much encouraging hitherto in an environment where the investment targets that have been set in the last year or two have not quite been satisfied, not least as a result of the increasing competition for investment capital elsewhere in the region. They run the risk also on the Malaysian side of losing the transfer of Australian technology, which has been one of the fundamental advantages that have been derived so often from Malaysian business association with Australia.

Perhaps the biggest risk of all, however, if this political or diplomatic disagreement is allowed to get to the point of fundamental deterioration in relations and economic embargoes, boycotts or whatever, the fundamental point that has to be contemplated on the Malaysian side, is the implications of this in terms of demonstration effect to other countries and investors in other countries who may well be minded to think very clearly about the risks of incurring really serious economic problems as a result of political problems arising in the relationship. That is not a message I think any country should be comfortable in giving elsewhere.

I mention those points just in passing. I do not particularly want to dwell upon them or dwell in any other way on the possible disbenefits for the Malaysian side that might flow if we get forced into some kind of crazy tit for tat retaliatory situation in the future. It is something that in both our interests we should be wanting absolutely to avoid.

I have talked only about the elements of the bilateral relationship. I have not talked at all—I could at considerable length but I will not, given time constraints—about the other kinds of cooperation that we have had with Malaysia over the years. I could talk about the way in which we have worked together to develop a new regional security dialogue, using in particular the mechanisms of the ASEAN consultative process, and the way in which we have worked together to establish the new ASEAN regional forum which will open up its first meeting next year. I could talk in terms of the way in which we have worked together in APEC, notwithstanding some of the difficulties that have been felt about full-scale embrace of that by the Malaysian leadership. As I have said in this place and elsewhere, there has been an extraordinarily constructive working role played by Malaysia in the development of APEC through the working groups, the committees and the other processes which have done the actual nuts-and-bolts work for the development of that emerging new regional organisation.

We have had tremendously cooperative relations with Malaysia in response to a whole variety of regional problems of a non-security or non-economic kind: for example, environmental issues, narcotics trafficking, reaction to terrorism, piracy and, in particular, the treatment of refugees—unregulated population flows—in the region. There is an enormous body of shared experience through the Commonwealth that is part and parcel again of our relationship with this country. All of these things are very important to reflect upon at a time like this; to reflect upon in Australia in a positive and constructive way and to reflect upon in Malaysia, I hope equally in a positive and constructive way.

The circumstances which led to the development of this difficulty are well known. The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) under the tail of a Boeing 747 aircraft in the Everett factory in Seattle, in circumstances that I and the Prime Minister have been at pains to spell out, should be understood in the context of the particular occasion. As I said in this place earlier this week, the Prime Minister had in fact been asked on numerous previous occasions about his attitude to Dr Mahathir's non-appearance at Seattle. On each occasion he had replied in absolutely neutral terms.

On 21 November, in the statement that this motion inappropriately characterises as intemperate, the question was put to Mr Keating in the form of a request for comment on a reported statement that morning in the New York Times by Dr Mahathir that `perhaps you have to thumb your nose at people before they notice you'. Mr Keating's reply did emerge on this occasion perhaps a little more sharply than it had on earlier occasions. But if it did so, it was clearly in response to the particular circumstance with which he was confronted: repetitive, aggressive questioning and a particular quote which did have a whiff of provocation about it which I think would be acknowledged by even the most objective observer.

Our diplomatic response accordingly in dealing with this issue when it first arose and when it first became clear that there was some concern on the Malaysian side—although we thought not such as to be producing anything in the nature of a formal protest, a point that we talked about earlier in question time today—was to make clear, through statements that I made and the general messages that were delivered at a diplomatic level, that there had been no intention to cause offence on this occasion, that the context in which the remark had been made should be clearly understood and we hoped that our mutual commitment to the value of the relationship would be such as to ensure that no real problems ensued and that we could draw a line under this particular situation.

The reply by the High Commissioner to the letter that initiated all this from the UMNO Youth Organisation was delivered in the first few days. We had hoped that that might be enough to restore normality to the situation. The response was a cautious, a careful, a low key one. It was not a negligent or negligible response, but it was certainly cautious and low key.

When it became clear in the course of last week, the second week of this matter, that it was necessary to take some further steps to explain Australia's position, Prime Minister Keating did, in fact, write to Dr Mahathir. He wrote in a way that made very clear that what he said was not calculated to cause offence. That language was starkly clear in the text of the letter. It may be, as I said earlier this week, that the rest of the letter was not as fulsome as might possibly have been thought appropriate on the Malaysian side. If that were so, I think that should be understood against the context of the total situation as it prevailed by then, which had involved a lot of statements coming from the Malaysian side and which had been, in turn, felt by Australia to be less than totally helpful in resolving the situation.

For whatever reason the letter, which the Prime Minister had hoped would resolve the matter, did not do so. It became clear that some expression of regret would be helpful in completing and rounding out the picture. Accordingly, the Prime Minister chose the opportunity of the Sunday program on the weekend to convey just exactly some such expression of regret. As a result of the content of the letter and the TV program, we have had a very clear statement of the Prime Minister's position from him, from his mouth and from his pen, on the public record—a statement which, in effect, says that there was no intention to offend and, if there was offence taken, then that was regretted. That has been combined with statements of expression of understanding of the significance of the relationship, of the warmth of the relationship and of our commitment to it.

Since the weekend, as the situation has further continued, and I have returned to the country and thrown off the fevers which made my life a bit miserable for the last few days, I have become fully involved in this situation over the last three days, with results that I have mentioned already in question time today. I do not propose to go into detail about the nature and extent of that diplomatic activity which is now occurring except to say that we are working very hard to try to resolve the situation. We believe the situation will be most helpfully resolved by a cooperative effort on the part of all Australians in this matter and with an absolute minimum of the kind of, with respect, vulgar and opportunistic point scoring that is inherent in the text of this motion, which we reject.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think even the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) would acknowledge that, in the area of diplomacy, words are bullets. Those words were used by a relatively more distinguished predecessor of the minister's; nonetheless, they remain very valid. Therefore, it is all the more extraordinary that we should have had the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 22 November not just showing his frustration and lack of self control by using that offensive term `recalcitrant' but saying that he could not care less whether Dr Mahathir attended the APEC meeting. Having considered the full consequences of his remarks, he then chose to go on Lateline and say that his remarks were merely part of the rough and tumble of international politics.

PARA.TAB: If words are bullets, the Prime Minister has comprehensively shot himself in the foot and has continued to do so since that time. It is extraordinary that again we have heard a very limp defence by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, who—for all his professed awareness of the significance of words—continues to misuse the word `fulsome', which means `flatteringly insincere'. I presume he does not intend those to be the words used to characterise the Prime Minister's choice of words.

The statement put out by a spokesman for the Prime Minister could give offence because it should have been put out in the first person by the Prime Minister, not by some flunkey or lackey on his behalf, giving every impression that the Prime Minister would not condescend to speak on the public record about the matter. He did not release the terms of the letter. He just put forward a case of self-defence, saying the issue had been blown out of proportion. What message does that convey to the Malaysians? It says someone else is distorting the issue and the Malaysians are taking offence unnecessarily. It also says that the Australian media is to blame, the Malaysian media is to blame or the Malaysian authorities have got it wrong. I would not have thought that to be in any way helpful.

The mantra that the Prime Minister's remarks in Seattle were not calculated to give offence has been repeated. Anyone on the government side ought to know by now that whether or not they were calculated to give offence, they most surely did. Yet we have had no acknowledgment from the Prime Minister that that was the effect and no regret at his choice of words. Who can blame the Malaysians for saying, as Dr Mahathir did subsequently, that he could not regard or define the letter as being conciliatory.

We have had yet another confirmation that the government has been far too clever by half in this very delicate area. It received what was clearly intended to be a formal expression of displeasure. The Acting Secretary-General of the Department of Foreign Affairs rang the Australian High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur and made it very plain that the Malaysians were very unhappy about the remarks made by Mr Keating. A statement was put out by a spokesman but it did not in any shape or form acknowledge that the Malaysians had concerns. It tried to pretend they were unconcerned by saying the Malaysian government had made no official protest.

That is very clever and semantic, as has been pointed out today. But it is utterly disingenuous and misleading. If the Trade Practices Commission had jurisdiction, it would find this an open-and-shut case of someone trying to give the impression, by misleading and deceptive conduct, that the Malaysians had nothing to worry about and had not really complained in terms that ought to be taken seriously. But we have had confirmation today from the minister's mouth that they did take it seriously. It is only a semantic point to talk about official protests.

What is the purpose of the exercise? Is it to make those opposite feel good; that on the Richter scale of diplomatic gaffes that is only about a six instead of a nine? Because it was not characterised by them as official; it was really a very strong and formal expression of displeasure. To go ahead and put out that statement inevitably would have the consequences it has had.

Even as late as today, Senator Cook—if ever there were a boy on a man's errand, it has to be the junior minister—is wandering around Malaysia saying there will be a change in the relationship between the countries but that Australia has done enough to try to heal the rift. I would have thought that everyone acknowledges—certainly the public opinion polls—that there is more that the Prime Minister can do. The Prime Minister should not say, like a schoolboy caught with his hand in the till, `I am sorry I got caught'. He should be saying, `I should not have used those words in the first place. Those words did not just have the effect of giving offence, but they were utterly inappropriate and should not have been used'. He should have acted much more quickly.

The Prime Minister thinks he can get away with this sort of conduct in the international arena just because he seems to be able to get away with it in the domestic arena where the press thinks he is very clever to use such terms as scumbag and all the other terms that have so endeared him to the electorate. He thinks he can go to Seattle, mix it with world leaders and use that sort of gutter talk. That betrays the Prime Minister's fundamental incapacity to exercise diplomatic skills.

It is therefore extraordinary that Senator Evans seems remarkably reluctant to put on the record any efforts that he has made to try to counsel the Prime Minister. One suspects that the real answer is that the Prime Minister does not want to know the views of Senator Evans. Senator Evans, in his quest to be the next Secretary-General of the United Nations, does not want to be tagged with the oafish behaviour of his parliamentary leader. Nonetheless, it is very surprising that, when the minister dealt with this issue last Monday, he said that we will do everything we reasonably can to keep the relationship warm and productive, but if a good relationship is to continue it must be wanted and worked for by both sides. He is again lecturing the Malaysians. He is saying, `It is not our fault. If you want to fix it up, you do it'.

He then goes on to say that it would be helpful if the Malaysian side were to acknowledge the circumstances in which Mr Keating's original remarks were made. That is another attempt to avoid responsibility and to somehow suggest that not only is the Prime Minister not guilty but also, if we look at the context, we will see it in a fundamentally different light. We know that is not the case; it is not the way it has developed. It is not the approach the Malaysians have adopted.

To say, further, that Senator Evans discovered just a few days ago that the Malaysian translation of `recalcitrant' is extremely insulting raises the obvious question as to whether this was brought to his attention by his departmental advisers and diplomatic representatives in Malaysia. If it was and Senator Evans did not act on it, there is a case to be answered. If they were not even aware of it—even though there had been a recent spat in the Malaysian press—one wonders what they do with their time.

I suspect that they did relay all this and the Prime Minister ignored that counsel and chose to tough it out. Senator Evans went on to say that the media and other key interest groups in Australia are much more likely to line up against a person or institution in question, assuming that if a criticism is made there must be some case to answer. The obvious implication of that assertion is that there is not a case to answer in this instance. All Senator Evans has done is compound the felony, making it clear that we will not take any further initiatives and that it is up to the Malaysians.

It is almost 2 1/2 weeks since this utterly undisciplined statement was made by the Prime Minister, yet events have indicated that the relationship is going from bad to worse. We can send as many Cooks and Rays as we want to Malaysia, but only one person can repair the damage; that is, the Prime Minister. But his ego stands in the way of any repair of the relationship. What we are stuck with is Senator Evans saying it is tough luck for Australian exporters. He said that if they are on the brink of losing hundreds of millions of dollars that is in the nature and hazards of business life.

We cannot expect people to factor in an avoidable and political risk of a Prime Minister running off at the mouth and fundamentally fracturing the relationship we have with one of our near neighbours. Only a few months ago, the Malaysian foreign minister was making it clear what a very good relationship we have. The deterioration since that time is the fault of one person.

He can send his junior minister and his Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to Malaysia every day of the week, but everyone knows that there is only one person the Malaysians will take any notice of, and he is the person who not only cannot bring himself to acknowledge that his remarks gave offence but also shows not the slightest remorse or regret and has uttered no expression of conciliation. He seems to be perfectly content to see billions of dollars in contracts with Malaysia put at risk.

Telecom Australia is keen to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the region. Malaysia plans to spend up to $10 billion through 1997 on telecommunications. This seems to be of no concern to the government which prefers to wriggle around and pretend it is everyone's fault except the Prime Minister's. We all know the facts of life. Even Senator Gareth Evans understands whose fault it really is. The sooner he starts to give some sensible and constructive advice—and better still, is listened to—the closer we might be to resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this censure motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which is before the Senate today. This motion states that the Prime Minister should be censured for:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . his failures to take appropriate action to prevent the increasing and continuing damage to Australia's relations with Malaysia, Australia's standing in Asia and Australia's significant trade with Malaysia arising from his intemperate remarks concerning the Malaysian Prime Minister.

It is very disappointing that a motion of this type has been moved because, essentially, it is so untimely, so unfortunate and so completely inappropriate. It is quite clear that such a proposition is ill-considered and, in my view, totally irresponsible.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston said that words are bullets in diplomacy. Surely that is an adage that applies as much to the opposition as anybody else. The talk about an undisciplined response would surely also apply to the remarks of Senator Alston and the opposition in this whole issue. Senator Hill talked about the need to be sensitive to the development of a relationship with Malaysia. I would suggest that that is good advice for the opposition to follow as well.

The Australian government has tried to resolve these issues in a manner befitting the difficulties facing our relationship with Malaysia at the moment—that is, in a manner befitting the very serious interests that are at stake between this country and Malaysia, and in a manner that clearly points out that our intentions were, essentially, not to cause offence to Malaysian officials, the Malaysian government or the Malaysian people, but to understand how significant is that relationship between Malaysia and Australia.

We can measure that significance in trade terms. We can point out, for instance, that currently the trade between the two nations stands at $2.4 billion. We can also point to the fact that the level of imports coming from Malaysia to Australia is very significant and growing—it grew some 17 per cent to $380 million in the last year. We can also indicate the very large level of exports from Australia to Malaysia, with Australia now being the 14th largest source of imports within the Asian region. It is also important to point out the assistance that Australia is giving Malaysia in education. As Senator Gareth Evans indicated today, the relationship goes far beyond mere trade matters; it goes to defence, to economic development, to a regional complexion, and also to a global complexion.

Given the complexity of that relationship, one would think it would be appropriate for all members of this community, all aspects of government—I include the opposition when I talk about government apparatus in this country—to have some consideration for the national interest and not seek to use quite opportunistic, undisciplined, irresponsible and totally ill-considered actions to try to embarrass the government at a time like this in an attempt to score rather simple and cheap political points which only serve to exacerbate the dispute. If the intentions of those opposite were really sincere, they would be talking about ways and means by which this dispute could be resolved, not adding fuel to the fire.

I also put those points about national responsibility to elements of the Australian media. There are times in any conflict when I believe that our national interest should be held above some of the more lurid aspects of our domestic political debate. There are times when it is the responsibility of certain sections of the Australian media to understand that their actions, in themselves, can inflame the situation. Just as it is the responsibility of all members of parliament to appreciate that their words are bullets, so it is the responsibility of journalists to understand that their words are bullets also.

I take the view, as expressed quite clearly in the Age yesterday, that the opportunity has been taken to try to point out the regret that has been expressed by the Australian government in an attempt to mend what is quite obviously a difficult situation. But there is no intention on the part of the Malays to treat this in a magnanimous way. We have to recognise those basic facts of life and we have to understand that, as the Age indicated quite clearly yesterday, perhaps now is the time for silence. I suggest it would be appropriate for this motion to be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this censure motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) moved by Senator Hill this afternoon. Malaysia is Australia's 11th most important trading partner. It is more important than many of the much bigger countries in the world about which we hear so much. It is a bigger trading partner for us than, for example, Germany, Italy, France, or even our close colleague and neighbour Canada. It is an even bigger trading partner than Thailand, which is one of the fastest growing countries in Asia.

PARA.TAB: Malaysia is one of the fastest growing economies in the world. Its average growth rate over the last five to 10 years has been between 10 and 11 per cent per year. As a result, some of our biggest companies—BHP, CRA, Amcor, Boral, Leightons and Transfield, just to name a few—have growing links with Malaysia. There are also many hundreds of medium and small companies about which we do not hear so much that are doing all they possibly can to build relations with Malaysia and the Asian region. We, and they, are so often lectured by the Prime Minister about the need to get closer to the region and build those relationships. They are sentiments with which we agree totally.

We also have longstanding defence and security links with Malaysia and, through them, with the region as a whole. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, so rightly referred to this afternoon, there are very strong personal relationships between many Australians and Malaysians. When I went to the University of Melbourne in the 1950s I was fortunate enough to number Malaysian students amongst my closest friends, and I am sure many others can give similar examples. Anything that damages that very important relationship is therefore a matter of most serious concern.

We now have on our hands a situation where there has been a fundamental rupture in relations between Malaysia and Australia which should never have arisen, but has arisen for one simple reason: the loose mouth of an arrogant and irresponsible Australian Prime Minister who made his remarks in front of television cameras when he was basking in the glory of the Seattle summit meeting. There, in front of the television cameras, he publicly bad-mouthed the leader of one of our major regional partners. That has implications not only for our relations with Malaysia but also for our standing in the region as a whole and our relations with other individual neighbours and partners within that region.

We really do have a very big problem on our hands which has occurred for two reasons. I have mentioned the first. Both of these form the basis of the coalition's censure motion of the Prime Minister today. The first is the Prime Minister's intemperate, irresponsible and ill-judged series of remarks in Seattle when he not only offensively called Dr Mahathir a recalcitrant but also, at the same time, used other very dismissive language in referring to him.

The second reason why we have this very serious problem today is that, having made that inexcusable mistake in the first place, the Prime Minister has then compounded the problem by his subsequent failure to take appropriate action to prevent—even to limit—the increasing and continuing damage to Australia's trade and other relations with Malaysia and the damage to our standing in Asia.

For all the rhetoric and pseudo-defence from Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Carr this afternoon in response to the coalition's censure motion, there is one fundamental point that cannot be overlooked: we have a problem that should never have arisen. Given that it arose because of the very ill-judged, intemperate remarks of Australia's Prime Minister, it could have been settled—very easily, we believe—by his taking early action to correct the wrong that he had done and the serious impression that he had left with Dr Mahathir. The fact that he did not do that is an enormous indictment of the Prime Minister and the government.

Although this censure motion refers solely to the Prime Minister, Senator Evans is deserving of equally strong criticism for his apparent failure to act in relation to this dispute. He is, after all, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. More importantly, he is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and his basic responsibility is relations between Australia and other countries around the world, particularly those in our region. The failure of Senator Evans to do anything at all about this matter until today—that is what he said at question time—makes it apparent that he has achieved precious little. Even worse, he said at question time today that the Prime Minister could say nothing more to resolve the issue.

The fact that Senator Evans appears to have either been mute or absolutely neutered in his role is a very serious matter in itself. It indicates a major rift between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Senator Evans has been less than forthcoming in his defence of the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister's actions. I think that in itself sounds important warning bells about our ability to conduct our affairs in other parts of the world and our relations with other countries.

Given our ties within the region, the Prime Minister of this country should know, understand and operate within the accepted cultural parameters of our neighbours. We expect foreigners to respect our cultural beliefs and our attitudes to other countries; rightly, they expect us to reciprocate. The fact that Mr Keating did not follow this practice—apparently he did not really know what he was doing and the implications of it—is an indictment of him and his ability rather than another country.

The media—as has Senator Evans in his attempts in this place in recent days to defend the indefensible—have made much of the fact that Dr Mahathir has not personally complained about the comments made about him. That is certainly the way the Prime Minister's office seemed to be briefing the press in recent days. Of course, that is very misleading. That is a nonsensical approach. Dr Mahathir could not say anything himself because—as honourable senators would know if they know anything about the culture of that region—it would be an admission that our Prime Minister had caused him to lose face. The fact that our Prime Minister does not know or understand that shows appalling insensitivity on his part.

For all of those reasons, the coalition regards the censure motion as a very important, very serious motion. The Malaysian cabinet is due to meet in three days time—on 11 December—to consider this matter. It is absolutely imperative that the Prime Minister, the Foreign Minister and the Australian government take all necessary action before that meeting on 11 December to ensure that, at the very least, we will try to do all that we can to redeem a very serious situation. It should never have arisen in the first place, hence the censure motion today, which I hope this chamber will support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Remarks have been made by the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating), which have given offence to the Prime Minister of Malaysia. I think we should be debating how we best proceed in this quite delicate situation. My personal view is that there is fault on both sides, and I have yet to hear that acknowledged by the opposition. The Prime Minister's remarks were made in a certain context, and we have all been under similar pressure from exhaustion and frustration.
—It is the Prime Minister.

—Yes, I acknowledge that we have high expectations about the behaviour of our Prime Minister as he travels and represents this country. We do not expect a lapse in cultural sensitivity. However, I make the point that we have been in this situation before. Back in 1991, Prime Minister Hawke conceded, through the then Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, that his remarks on the hanging of two Australians at that time had been `downright insulting'. Prime Minister Hawke accepted the blame for the rift in relations between Australia and Malaysia.

PARA.TAB: Here we are in the same situation in 1993. It raises a lot of questions. It raises questions about cultural sensitivities on both sides of the argument—for example, the fact that we are not to know the direct translation of the word `recalcitrant'. It raises the issue of the cost to both countries if the escalation of tension is sustained. There will be a loss of trade, a loss of investment, a loss of opportunity for technology transfer, and plain loss of goodwill, which takes a long time to build up.

The comments made by Senator Evans in this debate so far have been quite helpful in pointing out some of the tensions and in alerting us, as much as he can, to some of the actions being taken behind the scenes—actions that we are not privy to. I agree with him that a cooperative effort is necessary, but I do not think we should spend all of this debate dwelling on who is most at fault. We should ask ourselves: in a cross-party constructive way, is there any way in which we can contribute to breaking the impasse, repairing the damage and sending the sorts of signals that are appropriate to the way in which we will conduct future relationships with Malaysia? This comes down to a couple of questions: to censure or not to censure, and what sort of signal will that send in this delicate stage of negotiations; to apologise or not to apologise, and what that will mean.

That is why I am proposing an amendment which I will now take the opportunity to move. The Australian Democrats, for reasons that have a great deal to do with the sensitivities of the moment, would prefer to scale down `censure' to `regret'. I move:

Omit all words after "That the Senate", substitute "regrets that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has failed to take appropriate action to prevent the increasing and continuing damage to Australia's relations with Malaysia, Australia's standing in Asia and Australia's significant trade with Malaysia, arising from his intemperate remarks concerning the Malaysian Prime Minister".

SPEECH.PARA: The rest we can accept. I think the key point is that there has been a failure to act promptly in an appropriate way. We have seen the stand-off. We acknowledge there is blame on both sides. We also acknowledge the damage that that impasse can do.

PARA.TAB: I would have liked my amendment to have included an apology. It is possible for the Senate to say, `We can play a constructive role'. On behalf of the people of Australia, I am perfectly willing to apologise for the unintended offence given—because I think that it was unintended—but, for various reasons, that is unacceptable to both the government and the opposition. I simply make the point that we could have taken this opportunity to do so.

The question is: are we likely to revisit this situation? The Minister for Trade (Senator Cook) has visited Malaysia and the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is visiting at the moment. I am worried that focusing on the visits simply escalates the media attention. We should not exclude from comment in this debate the way in which the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir, singled out the Australian press, describing it as a naughty child who needed a spanking. In the circumstances, that was not a particularly helpful comment.

I hope that the opposition, by acknowledging the sensitivity of the ongoing behind-the-scenes negotiations between Malaysia and Australia and the need to break the impasse, will be willing to consider substituting the word `regret' for `censure'. Since it is impossible to attach or apply blame fairly, we should take the opportunity to make our point and move on constructively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the opposition in the Senate is moving a censure motion against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Such a motion is one of the harshest forms of discipline and the heaviest penalty that a house of parliament can move against a person. It is a large but necessary step for the opposition to take. Even Senator Kernot, who is in a conciliatory mood at the moment, would agree that the Prime Minister has used some pretty strong, rough language not only in the area of international diplomacy but all over the place.

PARA.TAB: The other night, the Prime Minister said that if people got in the way of the Native Title Bill they should be `knocked down'. No-one would mind his saying that the ideas should be knocked down, but he said that people should be knocked down. He continually uses language that is inappropriate for a Prime Minister. As quoted in the Senate today, `scumbag' is one example, but he uses many such terms.

We are not talking about just any person. We are talking about the Prime Minister of Australia, the person holding the highest office in Australia, the person that the majority of people have elected to govern Australia. Yet we continually see this Prime Minister use rough—not that I mind rough; I have been described as being a bit rough myself—and inappropriate language. We have seen the Prime Minister conduct himself in an absolutely discourteous manner—and he thinks he can get away with it.

Obviously, the Prime Minister was pumped up by what he saw as his success in Seattle at the APEC conference. He did bring some people together to discuss trade, but he did not need to use the language that he did. It was half-smart language coming from a half-smart person that has got Australia into very serious trouble. His excuse—`I did not really mean to offend'—is not taken into consideration in Malaysia.

Today, Senator Cook was quoted as saying, `The Prime Minister has done enough'. On the Sunday program, the Prime Minister said that he would not try again to make contact with Dr Mahathir—`I think what I have done is very reasonable'. I disagree with the Prime Minister because, if he had done enough, Australia would not be in the trouble that it is at the moment.

The Prime Minister is putting at risk $2.4 billion worth of trade between the two countries. Malaysia is our third largest export market in Asia, our 14th largest source of exports and the recipient of $32 million worth of aid. However, relations between the two countries are not getting any better; they are getting worse—they are festering.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you're not helping.

—In a way, we are helping by pointing out what needs to be done. The Malaysian foreign minister rejected a call by Senator Evans for a cooling-off period. On Saturday there will be a Malaysian cabinet meeting which will consider retaliatory action against Australia. Already, the Malaysian media are running hard a buy Australia last campaign.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Cook believes that the Prime Minister has done enough, and if the Prime Minister believes that he has done enough, they are both grossly mistaken because their actions have not got the desired response from Malaysia. I do not know what the Prime Minister should do but he should never have got himself into this situation. The Prime Minister has to rectify the results of his remarks. If that requires an apology on behalf of Australia, the majority of Australians would accept that it is human to err but it takes a big man to apologise. The Prime Minister has to do the correct thing to sort out the problems that he has created for Australia.

The government's response has been totally inadequate. Yesterday, Senator Evans showed complete insensitivity and a lack of appreciation of how business operates when he told the Senate that people are taking risks in spending hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising and business costs to break into the Malaysian market. Senator Evans believes that it is fair enough for businesses to wear the results of the Prime Minister's ineptitude. I can tell the Prime Minister and Senator Evans that that is not good enough. It brings to mind a firm in Queensland that both Senator Kernot and I know of, Voxson, which has had its Malaysian operation threatened. I referred to this matter yesterday. I know the trouble that the Longginou brothers have taken to open markets in Malaysia. They sent their daughter and son-in-law to manage their Malaysian operation.

Yesterday I received a letter from Mr Longginou saying that his daughter rang the Australian High Commissioner to Malaysia and complained to him about what was happening to their business. The high commissioner's response was that he had just got off the plane at 2.30 and he had had enough of the situation. He yelled at her and told her to stop panicking and politicking. He asked her, `Do you live in Malaysia or what? Do you have any idea of what goes on in Malaysia?', which reduced the lady to tears. She said that she knew the lifestyle in Malaysia because she had met him at his home when he first arrived in Kuala Lumpur.

The Managing Director of Voxson then called to speak to the high commissioner to establish his reasons for being so rude and abrupt to his daughter. His reply was, `Are you able to discern and read newspapers?'. No doubt the High Commissioner to Malaysia is under tremendous pressure. But that is the response that government representatives are giving to Australian business.

I do not care what the Prime Minister does. He has got himself into this situation; he has got Australia into this situation and he has got thousands of businesses into the situation where they are going to suffer financially. There will be casualties and there will be bankruptcies.

Yesterday I received a phone call from Kowari Motors in Townsville, which has had detailed discussions with Malaysia over the last year on a major contract for 100 tow trucks at $41,000 each. That is $4.1 million. The company was in a very favourable position. It had a far superior specification but was told last week by its Malaysian agent that:

SPEECH.PARA: Submissions from Australia would not be considered.

That is what is happening in the marketplace. This is what is happening to people who heeded the government's advice to go offshore and invest their money in Malaysia and in Asia, only to be sunk by the inappropriate remarks of the Prime Minister. Trade worth $2.4 billion is a lot of trade. It is hundreds of millions of dollars to the fruit industry, the sugar industry and the wool industry, which are all at risk because the Prime Minister has not got the ability to control his emotions. That is the problem: he has not got the ability to control his emotions. He has not got the mental discipline of a Prime Minister. For that reason, this censure motion should be carried—not because we are losing trade, though that is important, but because the Prime Minister cannot fill the high office to which he was elected with the degree of decorum that is required of a Prime Minister. If this is allowed to go on, he will offend someone else. He will offend another country. Therefore, I hope that Senator Kernot and the Australian Democrats, and the Greens, will support this censure motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I understand the sentiment of Senator Kernot's amendment and we share the view—although I know the government does not believe it—that the national interest is paramount in this matter. We want relations restored as quickly as possible in order that the opportunities, in particular for the Australian business people who are now suffering, might be returned.

PARA.TAB: Our concern, however, is that unless a strong message is sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) he simply will not listen. I have some doubts as to whether he will listen to the Senate, in any event. But the more we water down the protest in relation to his offensive statements and the damage that those offensive statements have done to Australia, the less impact it is going to have. On that basis, I would regret it, but there is not much point in our simply standing here and saying we are sorry that the Prime Minister has failed to take appropriate action.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are showing temperate behaviour.

—We are sorry. But I respectfully put to Senator Kernot that the Senate has got to make a statement to this Prime Minister to demonstrate that his conduct in relation to this matter has been intolerable and that the Australian parliament has got a right to expect better of him in the future. It has got a right to expect better of him subsequent to this statement, too.

PARA.TAB: I did not hear all of Senator Kernot's contribution, regrettably, but I did hear her say that there ought to be some support for what the government is doing now. That is okay, but really it did not go about mending this fence with any determination to achieve that goal.The whole atmosphere was one of Mr Keating doing the absolute minimum to try to get away with it without having to further lose political face, or however one might like to express it. His principal concern when he sought to overcome the difficulties that he had created was not the interests of Australia but the interest of himself. That is not good enough. That is why I regret to say that we cannot support the Australian Democrats' amendment because we just do not think it sends the message that the Senate ought to be sending to Mr Keating in these circumstances.
Amendment negatived.

That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an absolutely enormous document which was not available until tabling. However, I think it is a very significant document. It is particularly significant because in this case one of the assistant commissioners to the Resource Assessment Commission, Commissioner Bob Graham, went to the extent of making a separate and dissenting report.

PARA.TAB: It certainly seems to me that Bob Graham has gone a great deal further and into a great deal more detail than the other commissioners of the Resource Assessment Commission. This indeed is a very important matter. I think everybody in this chamber would recognise that the coastal management of Australia has been disastrous and that we have a large and increasing number of degraded areas around this country.

The report, in its main conclusions and in the dissenting report, identifies that a national perspective, a national strategy and a national approach are required. Therefore, this will clearly require an ongoing involvement of the federal government. It is not sufficient simply to leave coastal management to state and local governments.

A number of issues are common to the whole of Australia: problems of the development of frontal dunes, pollution of watercourses which flow down into estuarine and marine areas, stormwater disposal, inappropriate coastal developments, garbage disposal and the like, as well as the more serious and point impacts of mining for beach sands.

The dissenting report draws particular attention to the fact that the main report looks broadly at the issues. While the dissenting report agrees that the very broad issues are important and must be addressed, nonetheless a lot of the damage that is going on along our coastlines is being caused by a large number of incremental impacts. The main report does not deal adequately with that at all. We need to put appropriate strategies in place by which those incremental impacts will be adequately controlled. That means getting down to the detail of planning and what goes on at the local level, but it must be seen within the context of the big picture.
Bob Graham, in one part of the report, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I do not believe that the recommendations and proposals contained in the report of my fellow Commissioners provides a sufficient base to address the very real questions of managing the use and the development of Australia's coastal zone resources.

I think that is a very important qualifier. Anybody reading this report needs to take that on board seriously. The main part of the report adequately deals with an address on the very serious problems on the coastline.

PARA.TAB: During the inquiry it became obvious that major differences had emerged over the approach to be taken in the report. As Bob Graham says, the report focuses on the big picture. However, it fails to recognise the seriousness and the urgency of the problems facing the coastal zone. Probably the most serious problem, as I have said, is the tyranny of small decisions—and they need to be picked up. Little by little, the integrity of the coastline is whittled away by incrementally small scale development which, over time, leads to major and then irreversible changes in the coastline ecosystem.

We need look no further than the eastern seaboard where now an almost seamless strip of residential sprawl has robbed us of a pristine and biologically diverse environment. If no action is taken to stem this spread of human settlement—the report itself points out that over 80 per cent of people live on the Australian coastline—then we will see the complete removal, outside of national parks, of a natural coastline.

The dissenting report reflects the critical situation that Australians face today to save our coastal zone. It presents an excellent account of management prescriptions for the area and notes that new and innovative approaches to planning need to be developed; policies need to be made to work, implemented and enforced; local communities need to be empowered so that they can participate in policy making and policy implementation; management practices need to be integrated across a number of areas; and a nationally based monitoring program should be established to evaluate the effectiveness of management and changes in resource use.

Admittedly, the money raised goes towards research on the barrier reef, but one has to raise the question of whether this should not come from the general revenue, bearing in mind the enormous contribution that tourism already makes to the general revenue. I have received some answers from the department to questions I raised at the estimates committee about the complaints and difficulties experienced by operators in facilitating this tax. There are quite a number of them, which I will make further comment on at some other time.

I am also pleased to see the report mention the very important issue of oil spill prevention, and I am pleased to see that there is a review under way to see whether ships should come inside or outside the barrier reef. It will be very interesting to see what conclusion that report comes to. I am pleased, as I of course would have expected, that the authority is very involved in that.

A matter of some concern is that a tourist operator in the Cairns region has been prevented from proceeding with a tourism activity around—not on—Fitzroy Island off Cairns, one of the islands that has been claimed by Aboriginals pursuant to Mabo. It is pleasing to see that reported on in the report and that the independent review that was conducted at some considerable expense came to the conclusion that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority acted properly in giving permits for Magnetic Keys.

The committee did a good job, I might say, under impossible time constraints and brought down a report, particularly a dissenting report, that was very informative. We are not talking about all the amendments of the Democrats, or some of our amendments, or those of the Greens; this is the government amending its own piece of legislation even before it goes through the final legislative process. What a shambles. What an unprecedented shambles.

It is an embarrassment. They should be humiliated by this. TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that this industrial relations legislation ought to be referred back to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for further consideration, because of the unbelievable and unacceptable way in which the government has dealt with this legislation not only in this chamber but also in the other place.

I want to say that this is an absolutely ridiculous situation. We can go back through all this legislation, yet matters dealing with industrial relations have not yet been consolidated into a single document with which we can logically and sensibly follow this through. It begs the question: what hope has the public got of following what this government is trying to do? The answer to that is: absolutely and totally none. It is a most unsatisfactory position.

I do not know who we are supposed to blame in this exercise. Is it incompetence by the government? Is it lack of resources in the department or is it incompetence in the department? Why is the Senate put in a position whereby it cannot get these various bits and pieces consolidated into one act?

Linking it back to these other acts will create more confusion in the mind of the public. I might add that I have heard what I might call some unfortunate comments in this place today with regard to some of the letters that have been received. I have now received over 500 letters from very concerned people. I certainly believe that the people who have sent those letters to me have done so because they are very concerned about what is happening.

On the other side of the coin, there are people in the work force who also have a right to be able to get hold of a consolidated piece of legislation, or their organisations have, so that they know exactly where they stand as far as the industrial relations law is concerned and no situation is created whereby individuals find themselves breaking the law through no fault of their own. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) whether he would indicate to the committee the clauses relating to the heads of power utilised by the government for the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. I know that might be a strange request, but I think it is relevant, having regard to clauses 1 to 3 of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators may have noted that I have not entered this debate thus far. I have done that quite deliberately. I am somewhat concerned about the implications of the use which is being made of certain heads of power for the validity of certain clauses of this bill. Of course, it is not that I am not interested in this subject. I have been involved for almost 40 years in the industrial relations arena. As honourable senators know, next year is the 90th anniversary of the first arbitration act, which relied for its validity on the conciliation and arbitration power in the constitution. I understand the pressures that are being applied to the government to make an amendment to the Industrial Relations Act to allow greater flexibility. I am also conscious, however, of the fact that we have very high unemployment and that, whereas the bargaining boot was on the foot of employees some 20 years ago, it is now on the foot of the employers.

I recall very well opposing strenuously those of the extreme left who, some 30 years ago, rallied to the call of `Smash the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; destroy it'. They sought to do that because they believed in the survival of the fittest. That is not a philosophy that I subscribed to then and I do not subscribe to that philosophy now. There were innumerable battles within the trade union movement over that particular aspect. I am somewhat concerned—although I realise we have passed on—that in this bill the government is relying more extensively than heretofore on heads of power other than the conciliation and arbitration head of power.

That is a double-edged sword, of course. It is the extent to which these powers—I will not call them precedents because I suppose the corporations power and the external affairs power have been used in other circumstances—are being used, the validity of this measure, that concerns me. I am fully aware of the need for flexibility and modernisation, as it were, of the processes of industrial relations. But the rights of all concerned—both the employer and the employee—must be upheld.

The founders of our constitution, the drafters and the approvers, were also very well aware of that. Those principles have not changed. The need for protection of the interests of the participants in the industrial relations system has not changed. In order to have industrial progress, the parties to any system must desire to see that system work. I am a little afraid that we may be going along a path which might see that desire dwindle and we might end up with greater problems than the ones we are trying to solve.

My purpose in rising at this stage is to ask the minister whether he can identify now, or at some stage, those heads of power that have been used for the validity of this bill. Specifically—if it is not too much trouble—could he identify the clauses and the heads of power that are utilised to establish the validity of each of those clauses?

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments are fully in line with those of my colleague Senator Harradine. Therefore, it is probably best if they are tackled together. There will be a philosophical difference between people in this chamber—I do not know whether that is a good thing or a bad thing. Nonetheless, the constitution, as it has operated in this country, has served to restrict federal powers in this area and preserve certain rights for the states.

PARA.TAB: I do not purport to answer the questions that Senator Harradine has raised, but my understanding is that this bill relies on at least six ILO conventions, which will provide, in effect, heads of power for quite a number of these clauses—including some of the more controversial ones. I think Senator Harradine is right to point out to this chamber that, in heading down this road, the government is setting up a whole host of dangerous precedents; precedents which may ultimately come back to haunt those who are so blatantly—and, I believe, so wilfully—using international conventions.

I will perhaps refine this issue a little, because I think there is a very interesting example in one area of this bill regarding the termination of employment. It is my understanding that this relies very substantially on ILO convention No. 158, which was ratified by the government during the election period. My first question is with respect to that section of the bill that relates to termination of employment. Am I right in assuming that it relies very heavily on ILO convention 158? Secondly, am I right in assuming that this was in fact ratified during the caretaker period of government, which is not a time for governments to make very serious decisions?

Thirdly, it is my understanding that ILO conventions typically go through a number of processes, such as consultation with states, consultation with various officers in departments around the states and consultation with employers and unions. I want to make this point very clear because I suspect there will be High Court challenges relating to what I believe is the wilful attempt to use the external affairs power. Was there any consultation with the states? If so, what was the nature of that consultation? Did the states agree with the ratification of the ILO convention?

It is my understanding—I would like this to be confirmed—that an ILO convention is not ratified until we ensure that a nation's laws reflect that convention. In other words, the convention comes after the changes have been made rather than preceding the changes. I would like Senator McMullan's comments on that because my understanding is that in no way, given the wording of the convention, do Australia's laws currently come within the ambit of ILO convention 158.

Finally, am I right in saying that only three industrial nations—France, Sweden and Spain—have ratified this convention; the other countries which have ratified it being essentially African countries, the lesser developed countries? I put this question very seriously to Senator McMullan because I believe this is one of the clauses which will cause enormous trouble for industry. None of our major competitors have ratified this clause, particularly those in the region of the world with which we now find ourselves trading.
